Nuthook: A hook at the end of a pole to pull down boughs for gathering the nuts.
Nathmore: Not the more; never the more.
nurseling: An infant considered in relation to its nurse.
Nepenthe: A drug used by the ancients to give relief from pain and sorrow; -- by some supposed to have been opium or hasheesh.  Hence, anything soothing and comforting.
&Verbar;Notandum: A thing to be noted or observed; a notable fact; -- chiefly used in the plural.
Nursling: One who, or that which, is nursed; an infant; a fondling.
Nide: A nestful; a brood; as, a nide of pheasants.
Northman: One of the inhabitants of the north of Europe; esp., one of the ancient Scandinavians; a Norseman.
Naphtha: The complex mixture of volatile, liquid, inflammable hydrocarbons, occurring naturally, and usually called crude petroleum, mineral oil, or rock oil.
Nasty: Offensively filthy; very dirty, foul, or defiled; disgusting; nauseous.
&Verbar;Nepa: A genus of aquatic hemipterous insects.  The species feed upon other insects and are noted for their voracity; -- called also scorpion bug and water scorpion.
Nitroprussic: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, a complex acid called nitroprussic acid, obtained indirectly by the action of nitric acid on potassium ferrocyanide (yellow prussiate), as a red crystalline unstable substance.  It forms salts called nitroprussides, which give a rich purple color with alkaline sulphides.
Nonelect: A person or persons not elected, or chosen, to salvation.
Nonagesimal: The middle or highest point of the part of the ecliptic which is at any given moment above the horizon.  It is the ninetieth degree of the ecliptic, reckoned from the points in which it is intersected by the horizon.
nontaxable: Not subject to taxation; -- of goods imported into a country or sold at retail outlets; as, most laws imposing sales taxes make food nontaxable.  Opposite of taxable.
Natals: One's birth, or the circumstances attending it.
nonmodern: not modern; of or characteristic of an earlier time.  Opposite of modern.
&Verbar;Neomenoidea: A division of vermiform gastropod mollusks, without a shell, belonging to the Isopleura.
Neuralgic: Of or pertaining to, or having the character of, neuralgia; as, a neuralgic headache.
naturalist: One versed in natural science; a student of natural history, esp. of the natural history of plants or animals; a botanist or zoologist.
nightbird: A person who likes to be active late at night; a night owl.
nigger: A negro; -- in vulgar derision or depreciation.  It is usually intended and interpreted as highly insulting and vulgar.
notifying: The act or process of informing by words.
Nepalese: A native or natives of Nepal, or an inhabitant of Nepal.
Nocturnal: An instrument formerly used for taking the altitude of the stars, etc., at sea.
Nageia: A small genus of Asian evergreen trees having columnar crowns and distinguished by leaves lacking a midrib; eastern Asia including India and Philippines and New Guinea.
Nightmare: A fiend or incubus formerly supposed to cause trouble in sleep.
Notelet: A little or short note; a billet.
Negative: To prove unreal or untrue; to disprove.
Neoteric: One of modern times; a modern.
naid: Any one of numerous species of small, fresh-water, chætopod annelids of the tribe Naidina.  They belong to the Oligochæta.
Nucament: A catkin or ament; the flower cluster of the hazel, pine, willow, and the like.
Nayword: A byword; a proverb; also, a watchword.
Nautiloid: Like or pertaining to the nautilus; shaped like a nautilus shell.
Nebulize: To reduce (as a liquid) to a fine spray or vapor; to atomize.
nubia: A light fabric of wool, worn on the head by women; a cloud.
Nigritic: Pertaining to, or having the characteristics of, negroes, or of the Negritos, Papuans, and the Melanesian races; negritic.
Norland: The land in the north; north country.
nosedive: To drop with the nose or front first, as of an airplane.
Nectostem: That portion of the axis which bears the nectocalyces in the Siphonophora.
Necromancer: One who practices necromancy; a sorcerer; a wizard.
Nibble: To bite upon something gently or cautiously; to eat a little of a thing, as by taking small bits cautiously; as, fishes nibble at the bait.
Nautical: Of or pertaining to seamen, to the art of navigation, or to ships; as, nautical skill.
&Verbar;Nouveau riche: A person newly rich.  Contrasted with old money.
Nemesis: The goddess of retribution or vengeance; hence, retributive justice personified; divine vengeance.
Ningirsu: The Babylonian god of war and agriculture, in an older pantheon.
Neuridin: A nontoxic base, C5H14N2, found in the putrescent matters of flesh, fish, decaying cheese, etc.
night-line: A fishing line with baited hooks left in the water to catch fish over night.
Nitride: A binary compound of nitrogen with a more metallic element or radical; as, boric nitride.
Nitraniline: Any one of a series of nitro derivatives of aniline; nitroaniline. In general they are yellow crystalline substances.
naprapathy: A drugless method of treatment based on the belief that disease symptoms arise from problems with ligaments and connective tissues.
Nundination: Traffic at fairs; marketing; buying and selling.
Nopal: A cactaceous plant (Nopalea cochinellifera), originally Mexican, on which the cochineal insect feeds, and from which it is collected.  The name is sometimes given to other species of Cactaceæ.
Necessary: A thing that is necessary or indispensable to some purpose; something that one can not do without; a requisite; an essential; -- used chiefly in the plural; as, the necessaries of life.
Norlander: A northener; a person from the north country.
noninheritable: not capable of transmission by heredity.  Opposite of inheritable.
naive: Having native or unaffected simplicity; ingenuous; artless; frank; as, naïve manners; a naïve person; naïve and unsophisticated remarks.
Nonresistant: One who maintains that no resistance should be made to constituted authority, even when unjustly or oppressively exercised; one who advocates or practices absolute submission.
&Verbar;Non compos: Not of sound mind; not having the regular use of reason; hence, also, as a noun, an idiot; a lunatic; one devoid of reason, either by nature or from accident.
Neuro-epidermal: Pertaining to, or giving rise to, the central nervous system and epidermis; as, the neuroepidermal, or epiblastic, layer of the blastoderm.
Natatorious: Adapted for swimming; -- said of the legs of certain insects.
Nuytsia: A genus consisting of only one species.
Navigerous: Bearing ships; capable of floating vessels.
niobium: The chemical element of atomic number 41.  Chemical symbol Nb.  Atomic weight 92.91.  Previously called columbium. See also Columbium.
Native steel: A sort of steel which has been found where a burning coal seam had reduced and carbonized adjacent iron ore.
Naturalistic: Belonging to the doctrines of naturalism.
Nominatival: Of or pertaining to the nominative case.
nontelescopic: Not able to be contracted by a telescoping action; as, a nontelescoping tripod would be awkward to carry.
Nonalienation: Failure to alienate; also, the state of not being alienated.
Newfangly: In a newfangled manner; with eagerness for novelty.
Negotiate: To carry on negotiations concerning; to procure or arrange for by negotiation; as, to negotiate peace, or an exchange.
Nonelastic: Not having elasticity; not able to be stretched reversibly.
Neocosmic: Of or pertaining to the universe in its present state; specifically, pertaining to the races of men known to history.
&Verbar;Na\u00efvet\u00e9: The state or quality of being naive.
Nicker nut: A rounded seed, rather smaller than a nutmeg, having a hard smooth shell, and a yellowish or bluish color.  The seeds grow in the prickly pods of tropical, woody climbers of the genus Cæsalpinia.  Cæsalpinia Bonduc has yellowish seeds; Cæsalpinia Bonducella, bluish gray.
&Verbar;Non obstante: Notwithstanding; in opposition to, or in spite of, what has been stated, or is to be stated or admitted.
Nonsubmission: Want of submission; failure or refusal to submit.
Nettles: The halves of yarns in the unlaid end of a rope twisted for pointing or grafting.
&Verbar;Nematognathi: An order of fishes having barbels on the jaws.  It includes the catfishes, or siluroids. See Siluroid.
Nowel: The core, or the inner part, of a mold for casting a large hollow object.
Nephridial: Of or pertaining to a nephridium.
Narcotine: An alkaloid found in opium, and extracted as a white crystalline substance, tasteless and less poisonous than morphine; -- called also narcotia.
Nux vomica: The seed of Strychnos Nuxvomica, a tree which abounds on the Malabar and Coromandel coasts of the East Indies. From this seed the deadly poisons known as strychnine and brucine are obtained. The seeds are sometimes called Quaker buttons.
Nepaulese: Of or pertaining to Nepal (formerly written Nepaul), a kingdom North of India; same as Nepalese.
nitro-: A combining form or an adjective denoting the presence of niter.
Nasoseptal: Of or pertaining to the internasal septum.
Navigator: One who navigates or sails; esp., one who direct the course of a ship, or one who is skillful in the art of navigation; also, a book which teaches the art of navigation; as, Bowditch's Navigator.
Nombles: The entrails of a deer; the umbles.
Nosing: That part of the treadboard of a stair which projects over the riser; hence, any like projection, as the projecting edge of a molding.
Nostalgic: Of or pertaining to nostalgia; affected with nostalgia.
Newari: A language spoken in the Kathmandu Valley of Nepal.
nonterritorial: not displaying territoriality; -- of animals; as, a nonterritorial species.  Opposite of territorial.
Naphthene: A peculiar hydrocarbon fraction occuring as an ingredient of some crude petroleums, mostly mixtures of derivatives of the five- and six-membered saturated cyclic alkanes, cyclopentane and cyclohexane, having the general formula CnH2n.
nett: remaining after all deductions; same as net a., 3.  Contrasted to gross.
Nervousness: State or quality of being nervous.
Na-dene: A family of North American Indian languages including Tlingit, the Athabascan language family, and Haida.
Nodal: Of the nature of, or relating to, a node; as, a nodal point.
Ninescore: Nine times twenty, or one hundred and eighty.
Natal: Of or pertaining to one's birth; accompying or dating from one's birth; native.
Nebraskan: A resident of the state of Nebraska.
Neuropodous: Having the limbs on, or directed toward, the neural side, as in most invertebrates; -- opposed to hæmapodous.
Nematogene: One of the dimorphic forms of the species of Dicyemata, which produced vermiform embryos; -- opposed to rhombogene.
nervus: Any bundle of nerve fibers running to various organs and tissues of the body.
Nomography: A treatise on laws; an exposition of the form proper for laws.
Nyctimene: A genus of East Indian fruit bats.
Nasute: Having a nice sense of smell.
Nameless: Without a name; not having been given a name; as, a nameless star.
Nicking: The cutting made by the hewer at the side of the face.
Nazarite: A Jew bound by a vow to leave the hair uncut, to abstain from wine and strong drink, and to practice extraordinary purity of life and devotion, the obligation being for life, or for a certain time.  The word is also used adjectively.
Neuralgia: A disease, the chief symptom of which is a very acute pain, exacerbating or intermitting, which follows the course of a nervous branch, extends to its ramifications, and seems therefore to be seated in the nerve.  It seems to be independent of any structural lesion.
nutate: to rock, sway, or nod; usually involuntarily.
&Verbar;Naik: A chief; a leader; a Sepoy corporal.
&Verbar;Nototrema: The pouched, or marsupial, frog of South America.
namedrop: To refer to people that one assumes one's interlocutors admire so as to impress them; same as to drop names.
Necrolatry: The worship of the dead; manes worship.
Nereidian: Any annelid resembling Nereis, or of the family Lycoridæ or allied families.
Notidanian: Any one of several species of sharks of the family Notidanidæ, or Hexanchidæ. Called also cow sharks. See Shark.
nonliving: Not endowed with life; same as inanimate.  Opposite of living and animate.
neocolonialism: Control by a powerful country of its former colonies (or other less developed countries) by economic pressures.  In contrast to colonialism, in which one country controls another territory by military force.
nave: The block in the center of a wheel, from which the spokes radiate, and through which the axle passes; -- called also hub or hob.
Noncontent: One who gives a negative vote; -- sometimes abridged into noncon. or non con.
needleful: As much thread as is used in a needle at one time.
no-go: not functioning properly or in suitable condition for proceeding; as, the space launch was no-go.  Opposite of go, a.
Niece: A relative, in general; especially, a descendant, whether male or female; a granddaughter or a grandson.
Nummary: Of or relating to coins or money.
Nolleity: The state of being unwilling; nolition.
network: To connect together into a network; as, to network computers; to network the printer with computers.
&Verbar;Notornis: A genus of birds allied to the gallinules, but having rudimentary wings and incapable of flight.  Notornis Mantelli was first known as a fossil bird of New Zealand, but subsequently a few individuals were found living on the southern island.  It is supposed to be now nearly or quite extinct.
noisemaker: Any device (such as a clapper or bell or horn) used to make a loud noise at a celebration.
Numskull: A dunce; a dolt; a stupid fellow.
Notobranchiate: Of or pertaining to the Notobranchiata.
Napoleon: A French gold coin of twenty francs, no longer minted or circulated.  It bore the portrait of Napoleon I. or Napoleon III.
Nasopalatal: Connected with both the nose and the palate; as, the nasopalatine or incisor, canal connecting the mouth and the nasal chamber in some animals; the nasopalatine nerve.
Nectarean: Resembling nectar; very sweet and pleasant.
Neighboring: Living or being near; adjacent; as, the neighboring nations or countries.
Nemaline: Having the form of threads; fibrous.
Napha water: A perfume distilled from orange flowers.
Navajoes: A tribe of Indians inhabiting New Mexico and Arizona, allied to the Apaches. They are now largely engaged in agriculture.
Necked: Having (such) a neck; -- chiefly used in composition; as, stiff-necked.
nth: Last or greatest in an indefinitely large series; as, to the nth degree.
Nutmeg: The kernel of the fruit of the nutmeg tree (Myristica fragrans), a native of the Molucca Islands, but cultivated elsewhere in the tropics.
Nematocyst: A lasso cell, or thread cell. See Lasso cell, under Lasso.
Negritos: A degraded Papuan race, inhabiting Luzon and some of the other east Indian Islands.  They resemble negroes, but are smaller in size.  They are mostly nomads.
Nonsensical: Without sense; unmeaning; absurd; foolish; irrational; preposterous.
Numidian: Of or pertaining to ancient Numidia in Northern Africa.
Nigh: Near to; not remote or distant from.
National: Of or pertaining to a nation; common to a whole people or race; public; general; as, a national government, language, dress, custom, calamity, etc.
Nail: To fasten with a nail or nails; to close up or secure by means of nails; as, to nail boards to the beams.
Numerary: Belonging to a certain number; counting as one of a collection or body.
&Verbar;Narthex: A tall umbelliferous plant (Ferula communis). See Giant fennel, under Fennel.
Norimon: A Japanese covered litter, carried by men.
noncommercial: not connected with or engaged in commercial enterprises.  Opposite of commercial.
Napoleonist: A supporter of the dynasty of the Napoleons.
Neighborly: Appropriate to the relation of neighbors; having frequent or familiar intercourse; kind; civil; social; friendly.
Nestor: A genus of parrots with gray heads, of New Zealand and Papua, allied to the cockatoos. See Kaka.
Near beer: Any of various malt liquors (see Citation below).
Navigable: Capable of being navigated; deep enough and wide enough to afford passage to vessels; as, a navigable river.
needed: necessary; as, provided them with all needed equipment.  Opposite of unnecessary.
Nitromuriatic: Of, pertaining to, or composed of, nitric acid and muriatic acid; nitrohydrochloric. See Nitrohydrochloric.
Nidget: A fool; an idiot, a coward.
Novelty: The quality or state of being novel; newness; freshness; recentness of origin or introduction.
Naphthol: Any one of a series of hydroxyl derivatives of naphthalene, analogous to phenol.  In general they are crystalline substances with a phenol (carbolic) odor.
&Verbar;Nematocera: A suborder of dipterous insects, having long antennæ, as the mosquito, gnat, and crane fly; -- called also Nemocera.
Neighbor: To dwell in the vicinity; to be a neighbor, or in the neighborhood; to be near.
&Verbar;Neufch\u00e2tel: A kind of soft sweet-milk cheese; -- so called from Neufchâtel-en-Bray in France.
nonpartisan: free from party affiliation or bias.  Opposite of partisan.
Nomopelmous: Having a separate and simple tendon to flex the first toe, or hallux, as do passerine birds.
Nonyl: The hydrocarbon radical, C9H19-, derived from nonane and forming many compounds. Used also adjectively; as, nonyl alcohol.
Noddle: The head; also, noodle; -- used jocosely or contemptuously.
Narrower: One who, or that which, narrows or contracts.
Nutria: The fur of the coypu. See Coypu.
Nationalness: The quality or state of being national; nationality.
Nighness: The quality or state of being nigh.
Nonintervention: The state or habit of not intervening or interfering; as, the nonintervention of one state in the affairs of another.
nucleic acid: A natural or synthetic polymer consisting of chains of ribonucleotide or deoxyribonucleotide units.
napalm: A highly incediary liquid consisting of gasoline jelled with aluminum soaps, used as a weapon of war in fire bombs and flame throwers.
Nutritional: Of or pertaining to nutrition; as, nutritional changes.
Nitromethane: A nitro derivative of methane (CH3.NO2), obtained as a mobile liquid; -- called also nitrocarbol.  It has been used as a rocket fuel and as a gasoline additive to add power to the fuel, especially in racing cars.
no-see-um: Any of several minute two-winged biting insects of the family Ceratopogonidae that suck the blood of mammals and birds and other insects; also called biting midge and punkie.
&Verbar;Nyentek: A carnivorous mammal (Helictis moscatus, or Helictis orientalis), native of Eastern Asia and the Indies.  It has a dorsal white stripe, and another one across the shoulders.  It has a strong musky odor.
Nematoid: Of or pertaining to the Nematoda.
nagger: Someone (especially a woman) who constantly finds fault.
Nausea: Seasickness; hence, any similar sickness of the stomach accompanied with a propensity to vomit; qualm; squeamishness of the stomach; loathing.
Natured: Having (such) a nature, temper, or disposition; disposed; -- used in composition; as, good-natured, ill-natured, etc.
Nomadic: Of or pertaining to nomads, or their way of life; wandering; moving from place to place for subsistence; as, a nomadic tribe.
Nazaritic: Of or pertaining to a Nazarite, or to Nazarites.
norepinephrine: A hormone (C8H11NO3) secreted by the adrenal medulla; it also serves as a neurotransmitter, released at synapses; called also noradrenaline.  Chemically it is 2-amino-1-(3,4-dihydroxyphenyl)ethanol.  It is a precursor of epinephrine in the body.
Navew: A kind of small turnip, a variety of Brassica campestris. See Brassica.
Naphthyl: A hydrocarbon radical regarded as the essential residue of naphthalene.
Najadaceae: A monotypic family of aquatic plants having narrow leaves and small flowers; same as Naiadaceae; the naiad family.
no-goal: a nonexistent goal; as, he lived without a reason progressing toward no-goal.
&Verbar;Neomenia: The time of the new moon; the beginning of the month in the lunar calendar.
Nomothetic: Legislative; enacting laws; as, a nomothetical power.
Nefarious: Wicked in the extreme; abominable; iniquitous; atrociously villainous; execrable; detestably vile.
Nicotinism: The morbid condition produced by the excessive use of tobacco.
nematocidal: Having the property of killing nematodes; lethal to nematodes.
Numerable: Capable of being numbered or counted.
&Verbar;Noctiluca: That which shines at night; -- a fanciful name for phosphorus.
&Verbar;Nacr\u00e9: Having the peculiar iridescence of nacre, or mother-of-pearl, or an iridescence resembling it; as, nacré ware.
Nominally: In a nominal manner; by name; in name only; not in reality.
nonporous: Not porous; especially, not having vessels that appear as pores; as, nonporous wood.  Opposite of porous.
Necessarily: In a necessary manner; by necessity; unavoidably; indispensably.
Niggardliness: The quality or state of being niggard; meanness in giving or spending; parsimony; stinginess.
nonsubmergible: not submersible or submergible.  Opposite of submersible.
Nepheline: A mineral occuring at Vesuvius, in glassy hexagonal crystals; also elsewhere, in grayish or greenish masses having a greasy luster, as the variety elæolite.  It is a silicate of aluminia, soda, and potash.
Necrophore: Any one of numerous species of beetles of the genus Necrophorus and allied genera; -- called also burying beetle, carrion beetle, sexton beetle.
Necessitarian: One who holds to the doctrine of necessitarianism.
Nasturtium: A genus of cruciferous plants, having white or yellowish flowers, including several species of cress. They are found chiefly in wet or damp grounds, and have a pungent biting taste.
Nimbly: In a nimble manner; with agility; with light, quick motion.
Nimble: Light and quick in motion; moving with ease and celerity; lively; swift.
Nothingarian: One of no certain belief; one belonging to no particular sect.
Nowise: Not in any manner or degree; in no way; noways.
Niveous: Snowy; resembling snow; partaking of the qualities of snow.
Nauseation: The act of nauseating, or the state of being nauseated.
Noodle: A thin strip of dough, made with eggs, rolled up, cut into small pieces, and used in soup.
Nevertheless: Not the less; notwithstanding; in spite of that; yet.
Nodding: Curved so that the apex hangs down; having the top bent downward.
Noctidial: Comprising a night and a day; as, a noctidial day.
Neo-Malthusian: Designating, or pertaining to, a group of modern economists who hold to the Malthusianism doctrine that permanent betterment of the general standard of living is impossible without decrease of competition by limitation of the number of births.
Nap-taking: A taking by surprise; an unexpected onset or attack.
Nitroquinol: A hypothetical nitro derivative of quinol or hydroquinone, not known in the free state, but forming a well defined series of derivatives.
Northumbrian: Of or pertaining to Northumberland in England.
nichts: A quantity of no importance; nothing.
&Verbar;Nucha: The back or upper part of the neck; the nape.
&Verbar;Negrita: A blackish fish (Hypoplectrus nigricans), of the Sea-bass family.  It is a native of the West Indies and Florida.
nun: The 25th letter of the Arabic alphabet, corresponding in pronunciation to n.
Noseband: That part of the headstall of a bridle which passes over a horse's nose.
Neurenteric: Of or pertaining to both the neuron and the enteron; as, the neurenteric canal, which, in embroys of many vertebrates, connects the medullary tube and the primitive intestine. See Illust. of Ectoderm.
Novene: Relating to, or dependent on, the number nine; novenary.
Nonplane: Not lying in one plane; not planar; -- said of certain curves.
Nummulite: A fossil of the genus Nummulites and allied genera.
&Verbar;Nerita: A genus of marine gastropods, mostly natives of warm climates.
non-profit-making: not commercially motivated; not profit-making; nonprofit; not for profit.
&Verbar;Nyctalopia: A disease of the eye, in consequence of which the patient can see well in a faint light or at twilight, but is unable to see during the day or in a strong light; day blindness.
Nipple: The protuberance through which milk is drawn from the breast or mamma; the mammilla; a teat; a pap.
Noumenal: Of or pertaining to the noumenon; real; -- opposed to phenomenal.
Nave: The middle or body of a church, extending from the transepts to the principal entrances, or, if there are no transepts, from the choir to the principal entrance, but not including the aisles.
Neo-Scholasticism: The modern revival of the Scholastic philosophy, esp. of that of Thomas Aquinas, with critical revision to suit the exigencies of the general advance in learning.  The Neo-Scholastic movement received a great impetus from Leo XIII.'s interest in it.
Navelwort: A European perennial succulent herb (Cotyledon umbilicus), having round, peltate leaves with a central depression; -- also called pennywort, and kidneywort.
Naumachy: A naval battle; esp., a mock sea fight put on by the ancient Romans.
Navy: Having a color of navy blue.
neoliberalism: A political orientation originating in the 1960s, blending liberal political views with an emphasis on economic growth.
Newfangled: Newly made; of a new type or fashion; formed with the affectation of novelty; -- sometimes used to express disapproval or disdain.
nonrenewable: That can not be renewed; as, a nonrenewable option; books on that shelf are nonrenewable.  Opposite of renewable.
Nondelivery: A neglect or failure of delivery; omission of delivery.
Nudity: The quality or state of being nude; nakedness.
nor-west: Northwest; the compass point midway between north and west; at 315 degrees.
Naturize: To endow with a nature or qualities; to refer to nature.
nucleon number: The sum of the number of neutrons and protons in an atomic nucleus.
Nectared: Imbued with nectar; mingled with nectar; abounding with nectar.
Nacre: A pearly substance which lines the interior of many shells, and is most perfect in the mother-of-pearl.
nonparallel: not parallel; -- of lines or linear objects.  Opposite of parallel.
Neroli: An essential oil obtained by distillation from the flowers of the orange.  It has a strong odor, and is used in perfumery, etc.
&Verbar;Neishout: The mahogany-like wood of the South African tree Pteroxylon utile, the sawdust of which causes violent sneezing (whence the name).  Also called sneezewood.
Nonresidence: The state or condition of being nonresident,
Night: That part of the natural day when the sun is beneath the horizon, or the time from sunset to sunrise; esp., the time between dusk and dawn, when there is no light of the sun, but only moonlight, starlight, or artificial light.
Njord: Chief of the Vanir; god of the sea and winds and prosperity; father of Frey and Freya; sometimes subsumes Teutonic Nerthus.
&Verbar;Nizam: A regular soldier of the Turkish army. See Army organization, above.
Nucleoplasm: The matter composing the nucleus of a cell; the protoplasm of the nucleus; karyoplasma.
Nitrohydrochloric: Of, pertaining to, or containing, nitric and hydrochloric acids.
Nasobuccal: Connected with both the nose and the mouth; as, the nasobuccal groove in the skate.
Nab: To catch or seize suddenly or unexpectedly.
narcissism: An exceptional interest in and admiration for oneself.
Nonesuch: A person or thing of a sort that there is no other such; something extraordinary; a thing that has not its equal.  It is given as a name to various objects, as to a choice variety of apple, a species of medic (Medicago lupulina), a variety of pottery clay, etc.
Nag: A person who nags, especially habitually; called also nagger.
Nebulization: The act or process of nebulizing; atomization.
Narrator: One who narrates; one who relates a series of events or transactions.
Nitrification: The act, process, or result of combining with nitrogen or some of its compounds.
Necrophobia: An exaggerated fear of death or horror of dead bodies.
Nidulant: Nestling, as a bird in its nest.
Nitroxyl: The group -NO2, usually called the nitro group.
Nasally: In a nasal manner; by the nose.
Nephelometer: An instrument for measuring or registering the amount of cloudiness.
Northeaster: A storm, strong wind, or gale, coming from the northeast.
Noon-flower: The goat's beard, whose flowers close at midday.
Nestle: To house, as in a nest.
Nosed: Having a nose, or such a nose; -- chiefly used in composition; as, pug-nosed.
Nosel: To nurse; to lead or teach; to foster; to nuzzle.
Naturalization: The act or process of naturalizing, esp. of investing an alien with the rights and privileges of a native or citizen; also, the state of being naturalized.
neoclassicism: a revival of the classical Greek and Roman style in art or literature.
Noncombatant: Any person connected with an army, or within the lines of an army, who does not make it his business to fight, as any one of the medical officers and their assistants, chaplains, and others; also, any of the citizens of a place occupied by an army; also, any one holding a similar position with respect to the navy.
Needful: Full of need; in need or want; needy; distressing.
Nectareous: Of, pertaining to, containing, or resembling nectar; delicious; nectarean.
Nonappointment: Neglect of making appointment; failure to receive an appointment.
Nucleiform: Formed like a nucleus or kernel.
Ningal: An Akkadian goddess, wife of the moon god Sin.
Nonruminant: Not ruminating; as, a nonruminant animal.
Numismatologist: One versed in numismatology; usually called a numismatist.
Native: One who, or that which, is born in a place or country referred to; a denizen by birth; an animal, a fruit, or vegetable, produced in a certain region; as, a native of France; the natives are restless.
Nonoic: Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, nonane; as, nonoic acid, which is also called pelargonic acid.  Cf. Pelargonic.
Neoclassic architecture: All that architecture which, since the beginning of the Italian Renaissance, about 1420, has been designed with deliberate imitation of Greco-Roman buildings.
narcissist: Someone in love with hisself or herself.
Noisome: Noxious to health; hurtful; mischievous; unwholesome; insalubrious; destructive; as, noisome effluvia.
nonresilient: Not rebounding with the normal or expected velocity.
Neologize: To introduce or use new words or terms or new uses of old words.
Neatherd: A person who has the care of neat cattle; a cowherd.
Nonproficient: One who has failed to become proficient.
News: A report of recent occurrences; information of something that has lately taken place, or of something before unknown; fresh tidings; recent intelligence.
Naphthalene: A white crystalline aromatic hydrocarbon, C10H8, analogous to benzene, and obtained by the distillation of certain bituminous materials, such as the heavy oil of coal tar.  It is the type and basis of a large number of derivatives among organic compounds. Formerly called also naphthaline.
Newt: Any one of several species of small aquatic salamanders. The common British species are the crested newt (Triton cristatus) and the smooth newt (Lophinus punctatus). In America, Diemictylus viridescens is one of the most abundant species.
Nonylic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, nonyl or its compounds; as, nonylic acid.
Nobilis rings: Colored rings formed upon a metal plate by the electrolytic disposition of copper, lead peroxide, etc. They may be produced by touching with a pointed zinc rod a silver plate on which is a solution of copper sulphate.
Nonmoral: Neither moral nor immoral; having no connection with morals; not within the sphere of morals or ethics; not ethical; as, imagination is of its nature nonmoral; infants are nonmoral.
New Zealand: A group of islands in the South Pacific Ocean.
Nounize: To change (an adjective, verb, etc.) into a noun; to nominalize.
Nonuniformist: One who believes that past changes in the structure of the earth have proceeded from cataclysms or causes more violent than are now operating; -- called also nonuniformitarian.
Nitroso-: (&unr_; or &unr_;). (Chem.) A prefix (also used adjectively) designating the group or radical -NO, called the nitroso group, or its compounds.
Neoterize: To innovate; to coin or introduce new words.
non-Catholic: A person who is not a Roman Catholic.
Narcotic: A drug which, in medicinal doses, generally allays morbid susceptibility, relieves pain, and produces sleep; but which, in poisonous doses, produces stupor, coma, or convulsions, and, when given in sufficient quantity, causes death. The best examples are opium (with morphine), belladonna (with atropine), and conium.
Nonexportation: A failure of exportation; a not exporting of commodities.
Nailbrush: A brush for cleaning the nails.
Necktie: A scarf, band, or kerchief of silk, etc., passing around the neck or collar and tied in front; a bow of silk, etc., fastened in front of the neck.
Nursepond: A pond where fish are fed.
Nitriary: An artificial bed of animal matter for the manufacture of niter by nitrification. See Nitrification, 2.
norman: A wooden bar, or iron pin.
noncombustible: Not combustible; not able to burn; as, drapery should be made of noncombustible materials.  Opposite of combustible.
Nonsexual: Having no distinction of sex; sexless; neuter.
Nobody: No person; no one; not anybody.
nuclear winter: a hypothetical lowering of global temperature postulated as the aftermath of a full nuclear war.  The mechanism of such an effect depends primarily on the injection into the atmosphere of small solid particles, as soot from burning forests, which reflect sunlight and cause a reduction in solar energy retained by the earth.
&Verbar;Neurilemma: The delicate outer sheath of a nerve fiber; the primitive sheath.
newsprint: Cheap paper made from wood pulp and used for printing newspapers.
Navel: A mark or depression in the middle of the abdomen; the umbilicus; called also belly button in humans.  See Umbilicus.
New Thought: Any form of belief in mental healing, other than (1) Christian Science and (2) hypnotism or psychotherapy.  It was practised in the 19th century, and its central principle was affirmative thought, or suggestion, employed with the conviction that man produces changes in his health, his finances, and his life by the adoption of a favorable mental attitude.  As a therapeutic doctrine it stands for silent and absent mental treatment, and the theory that all diseases are mental in origin.  As a cult it has its unifying idea the inculcation of workable optimism in contrast with the “old thought” of sin, evil, predestination, and pessimistic resignation.  The term is essentially synonymous with the term High Thought, used in England.
Neat: Free from that which soils, defiles, or disorders; clean; cleanly; tidy.
Nonappearance: Default of appearance, as in court, to prosecute or defend; failure to appear.
Neography: A new method or system of writing.
Nickeline: An alloy of nickel, a variety of German silver.
Nerve: To give strength or vigor to; to supply with force; as, fear nerved his arm.
Natively: By natural or original condition; naturally; originally.
Numeration: The act or art of numbering.
nerve: One of the whitish and elastic bundles of fibers, with the accompanying tissues, which transmit nervous impulses between nerve centers and various parts of the animal body.
Nike: The Greek winged goddess of victory; identified with Roman Victoria.
Negotiousness: The state of being busily occupied; activity.
naturalized: Acclimated to a new environment; introduced from another region and persisting without cultivation; -- of plants or animals not native to a location.
Neurism: Nerve force. See Vital force, under Vital.
narration: The act of telling or relating the particulars of an event; a recital of certain events, usually in chronological order; rehearsal.
Negroid: A member of any one of several East African tribes whose physical characters show an admixture with other races.
Nutrition: In the broadest sense, a process or series of processes by which a living organism as a whole (or its component parts or organs) is maintained in its normal condition of life and growth.
nephthytis: Any plant of the genus Nephthytis.
Nostoc: A genus of algæ. The plants are composed of moniliform cells imbedded in a gelatinous substance.
Naturalism: A state of nature; conformity to nature.
Nyula: A species of ichneumon (Herpestes nyula).  Its fur is beautifully variegated by closely set zigzag markings.
neonate: A newborn child, especially one less than one month old.
Notochordal: Of or pertaining to the notochord; having a notochord.
Neonomianism: The doctrines or belief of the neonomians.
Notechis: A genus including the tiger snakes.
Nineteenth: The quotient of a unit divided by nineteen; one of nineteen equal parts of anything.
Notate: Marked with spots or lines, which are often colored.
Negligence: The quality or state of being negligent; lack of due diligence or care; omission of duty; habitual neglect; heedlessness.
Nassa: Any species of marine gastropods, of the genera Nassa, Tritia, and other allied genera of the family Nassidæ; a dog whelk. See Illust. under Gastropoda.
Nauseate: To affect with nausea; to sicken; to cause to feel loathing or disgust.
Neutrality: The state or quality of being neutral; the condition of being unengaged in contests between others; state of taking no part on either side; indifference.
Nulled: Turned so as to resemble nulls.
Numismatology: The science which treats of coins and medals, in their relation to history; numismatics.
nonworker: A person who does not work as s/he should.
Nock: To notch; to fit to the string, as an arrow; to string, as a bow.
&Verbar;N\u00e9bul\u00e9: Composed of successive short curves supposed to resemble a cloud; -- said of a heraldic line by which an ordinary or subordinary may be bounded.
Natalitial: Of or pertaining to one's birth or birthday, or one's nativity.
Night-faring: Going or traveling in the night.
Nucleal: Of or pertaining to a nucleus; as, the nuclear spindle (see Illust. of Karyokinesis) or the nuclear fibrils of a cell; the nuclear part of a comet, etc.
narine: Of or belonging to the nostrils.
nonpartisanship: An inclination to weigh both views or opinions equally; absence of bias toward any particular party.
Needle: To form needles; to crystallize in the form of needles.
Nobilitate: To make noble; to ennoble; to exalt.
Nestful: As much or many as will fill a nest.
Norroy: The most northern of the English Kings-at-arms. See King-at-arms, under King.
nu: The 13th letter of the Greek alphabet (ν).
Nonchalantly: In a nonchalant, indifferent, or careless manner; coolly.
&Verbar;Non est inventus: The return of a sheriff on a writ, when the defendant is not found in his county.
Neckband: A band which goes around the neck; often, the part at the top of a garment.
Notarial: Of or pertaining to a notary; done or taken by a notary; as, a notarial seal; notarial evidence or attestation.
Nammu: The Sumerian goddess personifying the primeval sea; mother of the gods and of heaven and earth.
Numerically: In a numerical manner; in numbers; with respect to number, or sameness in number; as, a thing is numerically the same, or numerically different.
Nacarat: A pale red color, with a cast of orange.
Ninib: A solar deity, first-born of Bel and consort was Gula; god of war and the chase and agriculture; sometimes identifed with Biblical Nimrod.
Niagara period: A subdivision or the American Upper Silurian system, embracing the Medina, Clinton, and Niagara epoch. The rocks of the Niagara epoch, mostly limestones, are extensively distributed, and at Niagara Falls consist of about eighty feet of shale supporting a greater thickness of limestone, which is gradually undermined by the removal of the shale. See Chart of Geology.
Nordic: of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Scandinavia; as, Nordic languages have a gender system.
Nobleman: One of the nobility; a noble; a peer; one who enjoys rank above a commoner, either by virtue of birth, by office, or by patent.
Nadir: That point of the heavens, or lower hemisphere, directly opposite the zenith; the inferior pole of the horizon; the point of the celestial sphere directly under the place where we stand.
Nonsensitive: Not sensitive; wanting sense or perception; not easily affected.
Nebula: A faint, cloudlike, self-luminous mass of matter situated beyond the solar system among the stars.  The term was originally applied to any diffuse luminous region.  Now, technically, it is applied to interstellar clouds of dust and gases (diffuse nebula).  However distant galaxies and very distant star clusters often appear like them in the telescope, such as the spiral nebula in Andromeda, known now to be a distant galaxy.
Nauscopy: The power or act of discovering ships or land at considerable distances.
Nonresistance: The principles or practice of a nonresistant; passive obedience; submission to authority, power, oppression, or violence without opposition.
Neurotic: A disease seated in the nerves.
Nomadize: To lead the life of a nomad; to wander with flocks and herds for the sake of finding pasturage.
Nestling: Newly hatched; being yet in the nest.
Nebuly: A line or a decoration composed of successive short curves or waves supposed to resemble a cloud. See Nébulé
Needlewoman: A woman who does needlework; a seamstress.
nothosaur: An extinct marine reptile with longer more slender limbs than plesiosaurs and less completely modified for swimming.
Nantua: A white sauce with whipping cream and shrimp butter.
Nonce: The one or single occasion; the present call or purpose; -- chiefly used in the phrase for the nonce, i. e. for the present time.
Noctuary: A record of what passes in the night; a nightly journal; -- distinguished from diary.
Nocturn: An office of devotion, or act of religious service, by night.
Nonpresentation: Neglect or failure to present; state of not being presented.
New-year: Of or pertaining to, or suitable for, the commencement of the year; as, New-year gifts or odes.
nationalize: To make national; to make a nation of; to endow with the character and habits of a nation, or the peculiar sentiments and attachment of citizens of a nation.
Nerthus: The Teutonic goddess of fertility; later identified with Norse Njord.
night owl: A person who likes to be active late at night.
Neuropore: An opening at either end of the embryonic neural canal.
Naughtily: In a naughty manner; wickedly; perversely.
Nomenclator: One who calls persons or things by their names.
Nuisancer: One who makes or causes a nuisance.
Nasopharyngeal: Of or pertaining to both throat and nose; as, a nasopharyngeal polypus.
nineties: The decade from 1890 to 1899; as, the gay nineties.
Necroscopic: Or or relating to post-mortem examinations.
Nautilidae: A natural family of spiral-shelled cephalopods.
nonbearing: supporting no vertical weight other than its own; -- of a structural member; as, a non-bearing wall.
nightie: Any loose-fitting clothing for wear in bed.
Nickel: A bright silver-white metallic element of atomic number 28.  It is of the iron group, and is hard, malleable, and ductile.  It occurs combined with sulphur in millerite, with arsenic in the mineral niccolite, and with arsenic and sulphur in nickel glance.  Symbol Ni.  Atomic weight 58.70.
norium: A supposed metal alleged to have been discovered in 1845 by the Swedish chemist Swanberg in zircon.  After many unsuccessful attempts to verify this new element, the element named Hafnium (atomic number 72) was discoverd in 1923 by D. Coster and G. von Hevesey in the zirconium-containing mineral zircon.  Hafnium, present at 1 to 5% in many zirconium-bearing minerals, but difficult to separate from zirconium, is probably the element that gave rise to the properties attributed to the hypothetical norium.
Nyctaginia: A genus consisting of only one species.
Nemophilist: One who is fond of forest or forest scenery; a haunter of the woods.
Nubbin: A small or imperfect ear of maize.
Nicker: One of the night brawlers of London formerly noted for breaking windows with half-pence.
&Verbar;Nares: The nostrils or nasal openings, -- the anterior nares being the external or proper nostrils, and the posterior nares, the openings of the nasal cavities into the mouth or pharynx.
N\u00e6void: Resembling a nævus or nævi; as, nævoid elephantiasis.
nuclear fusion reaction: A nuclear reaction in which nuclei combine to form more massive nuclei with the simultaneous release of energy.
Nonclaim: A failure to make claim within the time limited by law; omission of claim.
Neotropical: Belonging to, or designating, a region of the earth's surface which comprises most of South America, the Antilles, and tropical North America.
nagami: A shrub (Fortunella margarita) bearing oval-fruited kumquats. See also kumquat.
nebulation: The condition of being nebulated; also, a clouded, or ill-defined, color mark.
nother: Other; -- variant spelling used mostly in the phrase a whole nother (i. e., a completely different), as though formed by splitting the word “another”.
nuclear fusion: A type of nuclear reaction in which atomic nuclei combine to form more massive nuclei with the simultaneous release of energy.
Nebbish: A person who is ineffectual, timid, and often luckless; a person of no significance.
Noematachograph: An instrument for determining and registering the duration of more or less complex operations of the mind.
nonvolatile: not readily evaporated.  Opposite of volatile.
Nucleate: To gather, as about a nucleus or center.
Navy blue: A dark grayish blue.  Also called navy.
nylon: Any of several thermoplastic polyamide plastics, comprising a family of high-strength resilient synthetic materials, used mostly in fibers.
Nepenthaceae: A natural family coextensive with the genus Nepenthes.
Neuromere: A metameric segment of the cerebro-spinal nervous system.
Neologic: Of or pertaining to neology; employing new words; of the nature of, or containing, new words or new doctrines.
Necrotic: Affected with necrosis; as, necrotic tissue; characterized by, or producing, necrosis; as, a necrotic process.
Nailer: One whose occupation is to make nails; a nail maker.
Nemophily: Fondness for forest scenery; love of the woods.
noninfectious: not infectious; --of diseases.  Opposite of infectious.
Neocomian: Of or pertaining to the lower greensand.
Needler: One who makes or uses needles; also, a dealer in needles.
Nonacid: Destitute of acid properties; hence, basic; metallic; positive; -- said of certain atoms and radicals.
norethandrolone: a progestin compound used in oral contraceptives and to treat endometriosis.
needlewood: A large bushy shrub (Hakea leucoptera) of central and eastern Australia, with pungent pointed leaves and creamy white flowers.
nonparty: not based upon or representing political parties; as, a nonparty regime.
Nargile: An apparatus for smoking tobacco.  It has a long flexible tube, and the smoke is drawn through water.  Also called hoookah and water pipe.  Functionally similar to the hubble-bubble, a simplified form.
Neglectful: Full of neglect; heedless; careless; negligent; inattentive; indifferent.
Nautiform: Shaped like the hull of a ship.
Neptunium: A radioactive metallic element of atomic number 93, produced in nuclear reactors from Plutonium or Uranium.  Symbol Np;  The atomic weight of the most stable isotope is 237.0482.
Neural: relating to the nerves or nervous system; taining to, situated in the region of, or on the side with, the neural, or cerebro-spinal, axis; -- opposed to hemal. As applied to vertebrates, neural is the same as dorsal; as applied to invertebrates it is usually the same as ventral.  Cf. Hemal.
Nasalize: To utter words or letters with a nasal sound; to speak through the nose; to pronounce with a lowered velum.
Neurad: Toward the neural side; -- opposed to hæmad.
Neonomian: Of or pertaining to the Neonomians, or in accordance with their doctrines.
Negrohead: An inferior commercial variety of India rubber made up into round masses.
nervomuscular: Of or pertaining to both nerves and muscles; of the nature of nerves and muscles; as, nervomuscular energy.
Nardine: Of or pertaining to nard; having the qualities of nard.
Nuddle: To walk quickly with the head bent forward; -- often with along.
Neoplastic: Of or pertaining to neoplasty, or neoplasia.
Nunnery: A house in which nuns reside; a cloister or convent in which women reside for life, under religious vows. See Cloister, and Convent.
Napierian: Of, pertaining to, or discovered by, Napier, or Naper.
Numbers: pl. of Number. The fourth book of the Pentateuch, containing the census of the Hebrews.
Neem tree: An Asiatic name for Melia Azadirachta, and Melia Azedarach. See Margosa.
Nape-crest: An African bird of the genus Schizorhis, related to the plantain eaters.
nutgrass: A widely distributed perennial plant of the Sedge family (Cyperus rotundus, var. Hydra), which has slender rootstocks bearing small, edible, nutlike tubers, by which the plant multiplies exceedingly, especially in cotton fields.
nonexempt: Not exempt; subject to (some specified) rule.  Opposite of exempt.
&Verbar;Nudibranchiata: A division of opisthobranchiate mollusks, having no shell except while very young.  The gills are naked and situated upon the back or sides. See Ceratobranchia.
&Verbar;Non-ego: The union of being and relation as distinguished from, and contrasted with, the ego. See Ego.
Nonylene: Any one of a series of metameric, unsaturated hydrocarbons C9H18 of the ethylene series.
Natural product: A chemical substance produced by a living organism; -- a term used commonly in reference to chemical substances found in nature that have distinctive pharmacological effects.  Such a substance is considered a natural product even if it can be prepared by total synthesis.
Nerite: Any mollusk of the genus Nerita.
Noisiness: The state or quality of being noisy.
normalize: To make normal; as, to normalize relations with China.
Nonextensile: Not extensile; incapable of being stretched.
Neuro-: A combining denoting a nerve, of or pertaining to a nerve or the nervous system.
Numenius: A genus of birds comprising certain of the curlews.
Numbness: The condition of being numb; that state of a living body in which it loses, wholly or in part, the power of feeling or motion.
nightclothes: garments designed to be worn in bed, such as pyjamas, a nightgown, etc.
nuclear-powered submarine: A submarine for which the motive power comes from the energy generated by a nuclear reactor.  Same as nuclear submarine.
Nyctibune: A South American bird of the genus Nyctibius, allied to the goatsuckers.
necklaced: Wearing a necklace; marked as with a necklace.
nonstop: A flight made without intermediate landings between source and destination; as, how many nonstops are there to Dallas?.
Novennial: Done or recurring every ninth year.
Nicotianine: A white waxy substance having a hot, bitter taste, extracted from tobacco leaves and called also tobacco camphor.
Nappiness: The quality of having a nap; abundance of nap, as on cloth.
Nectarize: To mingle or infuse with nectar; to sweeten.
Nubigenous: Born of, or produced from, clouds.
Neglect: Omission of proper attention; avoidance or disregard of duty, from heedlessness, indifference, or willfulness; failure to do, use, or heed anything; culpable disregard; as, neglect of business, of health, of economy.
&Verbar;Nystagmus: A rapid involuntary oscillation of the eyeballs.
nosey: Offensively or intrusively curious; prying; nosy; as, a nosy neighbor.
Nicaraguan: A native or inhabitant of Nicaragua.
Naphthoic: Pertaining to, derived from, or related to, naphthalene; -- used to designate any one of a series of carboxyl derivatives, called naphthoic acids of the general formula C10H7.COOH, such as 1-naphthoic acid.
Number; -- the number designating place in an ordered sequence; as, no. 2.
nucleon: A neutron or proton, when contained within an atomic nucleus.
nuts: An expression of disapproval, defiance, or displeasure, as in: “Ah, nuts! My knife just broke.”
Neanderthaloid: Like, or pertaining to, the Neanderthal skull, or the type of man it represents.
Nippitate: Peculiarly strong and good; -- said of ale or liquor.
non-involvement: withdrawing from the activities of a group.
Negotiosity: The state of being busy; multitude of business.
&Verbar;Nirvana: In the Buddhist system of religion, the final emancipation of the soul from transmigration, and consequently a beatific enfrachisement from the evils of worldly existence, as by annihilation or absorption into the divine. See Buddhism.
&Verbar;Nivose: The fourth month of the French republican calendar [1792-1806].  It commenced December 21, and ended January 19.  See Vendémiaire.
Nappe: Sheet; surface; all that portion of a surface that is continuous in such a way that it is possible to pass from any one point of the portion to any other point of the portion without leaving the surface.  Thus, some hyperboloids have one nappe, and some have two.
nuclear engineering: The branch of engineering concerned with the design and construction and operation of nuclear reactors.
Nubble: To beat or bruise with the fist.
&Verbar;Noyau: A cordial of brandy, etc., flavored with the kernel of the bitter almond, or of the peach stone, etc.
Nappy: A round earthen dish, with a flat bottom and sloping sides.
Noisette: A hybrid rose produced in 1817, by a French gardener, Noisette, of Charleston, South Carolina, from the China rose and the musk rose.  It has given rise to many fine varieties, as the Lamarque, the Marechal (or Marshal) Niel, and the Cloth of gold.  Most roses of this class have clustered flowers and are of vigorous growth.
&Verbar;Neritina: A genus including numerous species of shells resembling Nerita in form.  They mostly inhabit brackish water, and are often delicately tinted.
Noberts lines: Fine lines ruled on glass in a series of groups of different closeness of line, and used to test the power of a microscope.
&Verbar;Nayaur: A specied of wild sheep (Ovis Hodgsonii), native of Nepal and Tibet.  It has a dorsal mane and a white ruff beneath the neck.
Normandy: A region of France divided into Haute-Normandie and Basse-Normandie.
Northwesterly: Toward the northwest, or from the northwest.
&Verbar;Nepeta: A genus of labiate plants, including the catnip and ground ivy.
Neckwear: A collective term for cravats, collars, etc.
Notophthalmus: One of the genera of newts, included in the family Salamandridae.
Natation: The act of floating on the water; swimming.
Niepces process: A process, now no longer used, invented by J. N. Niepce, a French chemist, in 1829.  It depends upon the action of light in rendering a thin layer of bitumen, with which the plate is coated, insoluble.
&Verbar;Nee: Born; -- a term sometimes used in introducing the name of the family to which a married woman belongs by birth (i.e. her maiden name); as, Madame de Staël, née Necker.
neutered: Deprived of sexual capacity or sexual attributes.
Necessitattion: The act of making necessary, or the state of being made necessary; compulsion.
nematode: Any worm of the phylum Nematoda; a roundworm; -- they are unsegmented worms having a cylindrical elongated body.  They may live freely in soil or water, or as parasites in plants or animals.
Neutralization: The act or process of neutralizing, or the state of being neutralized.
Nonacceptance: A neglect or refusal to accept.
nonfissionable: not capable of undergoing fission{4}; -- of atoms or chemical elements.  Opposite of fissionable.
Noninhabitant: One who is not an inhabitant; a stranger; a foreigner; a nonresident.
Nullification: The act of nullifying; a rendering void and of no effect, or of no legal effect.
nuclear-powered ship: A ship for which the motive power comes from the energy generated by a nuclear reactor.
nyala: A spiral-horned South African antelope (Tragelaphus angasi) with a fringe of white hairs along back and neck.
Nunatak: In Greenland, an insular hill or mountain surrounded by an ice sheet.
Neo-Latin: Applied to the Romance languages, as being mostly of Latin origin.
natural family: a group of living organisms classed as a family in a toxonomic classification.
Nutshell: The shell or hard external covering in which the kernel of a nut is inclosed.
nonsubjective: undistorted by emotion or personal bias; based on observable phenomena; objective.  Opposite of subjective.
Nitromagnesite: Nitrate of magnesium, a saline efflorescence closely resembling nitrate of calcium.
Nude: Bare; naked; unclothed; undraped; as, a nude statue.
Nighttime: The time from dusk to dawn; -- opposed to daytime.
Nonimporting: Not importing; not bringing from foreign countries.
Nazaritism: The vow and practice of a Nazarite.
nightmarish: Terrifying, as if in a nightmare{2}; resembling a nightmare{2}.
Nonstriated: Without striations; unstriped; as, nonstriated muscle fibers.
Nuclear device: an explosive device, whether used as a weapon or for other purposes, which depends for most of its explosive power on the release of energy from within atomic nuclei.  A fission device or a fusion device.
Nominalize: To convert into a noun; as, a nominalized sentence; a nominalized adjective or verb.
Neckmold: A small convex molding surrounding a column at the junction of the shaft and capital.
Nematoda: A phylum of worms, having a long, round, and generally smooth body; the roundworms.  They are mostly parasites, in plants and animals, but some are free-living in soil or water.  Also called Nematoidea.
Ninth: The quotient of one divided by nine; one of nine equal parts of a thing; the next after the eighth.
new-sprung: having just or recently arisen or come into existence.
Naphthoquinone: A yellow crystalline substance, C10H6O2, analogous to quinone, obtained by oxidizing naphthalene with chromic acid.
Nudge: A gentle push, or jog, as with the elbow.
Namtar: A demon personifying death; messenger of the underworld goddess Ereshkigal bringing death to mankind.
Ninhursag: The great mother goddess in Sumerian mythology, worshipped also as Aruru and Mama and Nintu.
Natrolite: A zeolite occuring in groups of glassy acicular crystals, and in masses which often have a radiated structure.  It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and soda.
Nickel steel: A kind of cast steel containing nickel, which greatly increases its strength.  It is used for armor plate, bicycle tubing, propeller shafts, etc.
Naphthide: A compound of naphthalene or its radical with a metallic element; as, mercuric naphthide.
nigella: any plant of the genus Nigella.
&Verbar;Neuroptera: An order of hexapod insects having two pairs of large, membranous, net-veined wings.  The mouth organs are adapted for chewing.  They feed upon other insects, and undergo a complete metamorphosis.  The ant-lion, hellgamite, and lacewing fly are examples. Formerly, the name was given to a much more extensive group, including the true Neuroptera and the Pseudoneuroptera.
non-engagement: Withdrawal from the activities of a group.
Neocracy: Government by new or inexperienced hands; upstart rule; raw or untried officials.
Notebook: A book in which notes or memorandums are written.
Noetic: Of or pertaining to the intellect; intellectual.
Netty: Like a net, or network; netted.
Noun: A word used as the designation or appellation of a creature or thing, existing in fact or in thought; a substantive.
Neck: To reduce the diameter of (an object) near its end, by making a groove around it; -- used with down; as, to neck down a shaft.
&Verbar;Nuance: A shade of difference; a delicate gradation.
Nutlet: A small nut; also, the stone of a drupe.
Neo-Lamarckism: Lamarckism as revived, modified, and expounded by recent biologists, esp. as maintaining that the offspring inherits characters acquired by the parent from change of environment, use or disuse of parts, etc.; -- opposed of Neo-Darwinism (which see, above).
Non-feasance: An omission or neglect to do something, esp. that which ought to have been done.  Cf. Malfeasance.
Notal: Of or pertaining to the back; dorsal.
Nondescript: A thing not yet described; that of which no account or explanation has been given; something abnormal, or hardly classifiable.
nonreflecting: not capable of total reflection of light; not polished or shiny; as, It is complicated to create realistic shading effects on nonreflecting surfaces.
Necromancy: The art of revealing future events by means of a pretended communication with the dead; the black art; hence, magic in general; conjuration; enchantment. See Black art.
Noursle: To nurse; to rear; to bring up.
Notorhizal: Having the radicle of the embryo lying against the back of one of the cotyledons; incumbent.
Nundinal: Of or pertaining to a fair, or to a market day.
Nerve-shaken: Affected by a tremor, or by a nervous disease; weakened; overcome by some violent influence or sensation; shocked.
&Verbar;Naos: A term used by modern archæologists instead of cella. See Cella.
Nagana: A disease of horses and other domestic animals, transmitted by the tsetse fly; any trypanosomiasis, especially the variety caused by Trypanosoma brucei.
Numeral: A figure or character used to express a number; as, the Arabic numerals, 1, 2, 3, etc.; the Roman numerals, I, V, X, L, etc.
Nephelodometer: An instrument for reckoning the distances or velocities of clouds.
nonbelligerent: A country which is not involved in a war.
nonflammable: Not easily ignited, and burning only slowly if ignited.
Nigrescent: Growing black; changing to a black color; approaching to blackness.
Nonunion: Not belonging to, or affiliated with, a trades union; as, a nonunion carpenter.
Nondecane: A hydrocarbon of the paraffin series, a white waxy substance, C19H40; -- so called from the number of carbon atoms in the molecule.
Nymphean: Of, pertaining to, or appropriate to, nymphs; inhabited by nymphs; as, a nymphean cave.
Name: To give a distinctive name or appellation to; to entitle; to denominate; to style; to call.
Noncommittal: A state of not being committed or pledged; forbearance or refusal to commit one's self. Also used adjectively.
Nosography: A description or classification of diseases.
Narwhal: An arctic cetacean (Monodon monocerous), about twenty feet long.  The male usually has one long, twisted, pointed canine tooth, or tusk, projecting forward from the upper jaw like a horn, whence it is called also sea unicorn, unicorn fish, and unicorn whale. Sometimes two horns are developed, side by side.
Notchweed: A foul-smelling weed, the stinking goosefoot (Chenopodium Vulvaria).
Natatory: Adapted for swimming or floating; as, natatory organs.
Neutralize: To render neutral; to reduce to a state of neutrality.
Neaped: Left aground on the height of a spring tide, so that it will not float till the next spring tide; -- called also beneaped.
Natural steel: Steel made by the direct refining of cast iron in a finery, or, as wootz, by a direct process from the ore.
Nigerien: A native or inhabitant of Niger.
Nucleoplasmic: Of or pertaining to nucleoplasm; -- esp. applied to a body formed in the developing ovum from the plasma of the nucleus of the germinal vesicle.
Napery: Table linen; also, linen clothing, or linen in general.
Neuropteral: Of or pertaining to the Neuroptera.
Nefand: Unfit to speak of; unmentionable; impious; execrable.
nonrepresentative: Not standing for something else.  Opposite of representative.
Nunchion: A portion of food taken at or after noon, usually between full meals; a luncheon.
Nastiness: The quality or state of being nasty; extreme filthness; dirtiness; also, indecency; obscenity.
&Verbar;Neurapophysis: One of the two lateral processes or elements which form the neural arch.
Narrow-minded: Of narrow mental scope; lacking tolerance or breadth of view; illiberal; mean.  Opposite of broad-minded, open-minded, liberal.
Nitrometer: An apparatus for determining the amount of nitrogen or some of its compounds in any substance subjected to analysis; an azotometer.
Nundinate: To buy and sell at fairs or markets.
Nauropometer: An instrument for measuring the amount which a ship heels at sea.
Nonconducting: Not conducting; nonconductive; not transmitting a fluid or force; -- used especially of electric current; thus, in electricity, wax is a nonconducting substance.
Nauseant: A substance which produces nausea; an emetic.
Nuptial: Marriage; wedding; nuptial ceremony; -- now only in the plural.
Nine-bark: A white-flowered rosaceous shrub (Neillia opulifolia, or  Spiræa opulifolia), common in the Northern United States.  The bark separates into many thin layers, whence the name.
&Verbar;Non prosequitur: A judgment entered against the plaintiff in a suit where he does not appear to prosecute. See Nolle prosequi.
Naughtiness: The quality or state of being naughty; perverseness; badness; wickedness.
Nodulose: Having small nodes or knots; diminutively nodose.
Numerally: According to number; in number; numerically.
Nervation: The arrangement of nerves and veins, especially those of leaves; neuration.
Nidamental: Of, pertaining to, or bearing, eggs or egg capsules; as, the nidamental capsules of certain gastropods; nidamental glands. See Illust. of Dibranchiata.
Niggle: To use, spend, or do in a petty or trifling manner.
&Verbar;Nullah: A water course, esp. a dry one; a gully; a gorge; -- orig. an East Indian term.
Necessitous: Very needy or indigent; pressed with poverty.
Nut-brown: Brown as a nut long kept and dried.
neutralism: a policy of neutrality or nonalignment in international affairs.
Neddy: A pet name for a donkey.
Nilometer: An instrument for measuring the rise of water in the Nile during its periodical flood.
Niello: A metallic alloy of a deep black color.
Nauclea: A small genus of evergreen tropical shrubs or trees with smooth leathery leaves.
nonstandard: varying from or not adhering to a standard; as, nonstandard windows; envelopes of nonstandard sizes; non-standard lengths of board cost more per foot.  Opposite of standard.
Nereid: A sea nymph, one of the daughters of Nereus, who were attendants upon Neptune, and were represented as riding on sea horses, sometimes with the human form entire, and sometimes with the tail of a fish.
Notchboard: The board which receives the ends of the steps in a staircase.
Nibelungs: In German mythology, the children of the mist, a race of dwarfs or demonic beings, the original possessors of the famous hoard and ring won by Siegfrid; also, the Burgundian kings in the Nibelungenlied.
Neediness: The state or quality of being needy; want; poverty; indigence.
Nenuphar: The great white water lily of Europe; the Nymphæa alba.
Neurokeratin: A substance, resembling keratin, present in nerve tissue, as in the sheath of the axis cylinder of medullated nerve fibers. Like keratin it resists the action of most chemical agents, and by decomposition with sulphuric acid yields leucin and tyrosin.
Nomancy: The art or practice of divining the destiny of persons by the letters which form their names.
Nevadite: A granitoid variety of rhyolite, common in Nevada.
Negotiator: One who negotiates; a person who treats with others, either as principal or agent, in respect to purchase and sale, or public or private compacts.
night vision: The ability to see in reduced illumination (as in moonlight).
nonintersecting: not sharing a common point; -- of lines, planes, or surfaces.
Nebo: The Babylonian god of wisdom and agriculture and patron of scribes and schools.
Nitrol: Any one of a series of hydrocarbons containing the nitro and the nitroso or isonitroso group united to the same carbon atom.
&Verbar;Non sequitur: An inference which does not follow from the premises.
Natterjack: A European toad (Bufo calamita), having a yellow line along its back.
Norian: Pertaining to the upper portion of the Laurentian rocks.
Numerous: Consisting of a great number of units or individual objects; being many; as, a numerous army; numerous objections.
narcissistic: Having an excessive love of oneself; egocentric; egoistic.
Nuclear physics: That branch of physics which studies the structure of and phenomena observed in atomic nuclei.
Needlefish: The European great pipefish (Siphostoma acus or Syngnathus acus); -- called also earl, and tanglefish.
&Verbar;Nethinim: Servants of the priests and Levites in the menial services about the tabernacle and temple.
Natal plum: The drupaceous fruit of two South African shrubs of the genus Carissa (formerly Arduina) (Carissa bispinosa and Carissa grandiflora).  It is also called amatungulu.
Netify: To render neat; to clean; to put in order.
Necropsy: A post-mortem examination or inspection; an autopsy. See Autopsy.
Nympholepsy: A species of demoniac enthusiasm or possession coming upon one who had accidentally looked upon a nymph; ecstasy.
&Verbar;Non liquet: It is not clear; -- a verdict given by a jury when a matter is to be deferred to another day of trial.
Nonexecution: Neglect or failure of execution; nonperformance.
Nicotian: Pertaining to, or derived from, tobacco.
Naphthalate: A salt of naphthalic acid; a phthalate.
&Verbar;Nectocalyx: The swimming bell or umbrella of a jellyfish of medusa.
Nihility: Nothingness; a state of being nothing.
Neuroc\u0153le: The central canal and ventricles of the spinal cord and brain; the myelencephalic cavity.
Nosesmart: A kind of cress, a pungent cruciferous plant, including several species of the genus Nasturtium.
Neapolitan ice: An ice or ice cream containing eggs as well as cream.
Nonproduction: A failure to produce or exhibit.
Nutant: Nodding; having the top bent downward.
nightrider: member of a secret mounted band in the southern U. S. after the Civil War, which committed acts of intimidation and revenge.
nutsedge: a widely distributed perennial sedge (Cyperus rotundus) having small edible nutlike tubers; also called nut grass.
&Verbar;Nelumbo: A genus of great water lilies.  The North American species is Nelumbo lutea, the Asiatic is the sacred lotus, Nelumbo speciosa.
Neuro-central: Between the neural arch and the centrum of a vertebra; as, the neurocentral suture.
neritid: An operculate seasnail of coastal waters with a short spiral shell.
Nitrophnol: Any one of a series of nitro derivatives of phenol.  They are yellow oily or crystalline substances and have well-defined acid properties, as picric acid.
neritic: Relating to the belt or region of shallow water adjoining the seacost; as, neritic fauna.
Natureless: Not in accordance with nature; unnatural.
Nationality: The quality of being national, or strongly attached to one's own nation; patriotism.
nodulated: Having nodules or occurring in the form of nodules.
&Verbar;Nefasch: Any fish of the genus Distichodus.  Several large species inhabit the Nile.
Nycthemeron: The natural day and night, or space of twenty-four hours.
Nidorous: Resembling the smell or taste of roast meat, or of corrupt animal matter.
Nose around: to look around or search, especially where one has no authority to do so; to pry; to be nosy.  Same as nose{2}, v. i.
&Verbar;Nougat: A cake, sweetmeat, or confection made with almonds or other nuts.
Nudation: The act of stripping, or making bare or naked.
nonstick: permitting easy removal of adherent food particles; -- of surfaces, especially of cooking utensils; as, a frying pan with a nonstick surface.
Nephritic: A medicine adapted to relieve or cure disease of the kidneys.
Nozzle: The nose; the snout; hence, the projecting vent of anything; as, the nozzle of a bellows.
Noctule: A large European bat (Vespertilio altivolans syn. Noctulina altivolans).
Neapolitan: Of of pertaining to Naples in Italy.
&Verbar;Nardoo: An Australian name for Marsilea Drummondii, a four-leaved cryptogamous plant, sometimes used for food.
Nitroglycerin: A liquid appearing like a heavy oil, colorless or yellowish, and consisting of a mixture of several glycerin salts of nitric acid, and hence more properly called glycerin nitrate; also called trinitroglycerin and glyceryl trinitrate.  It is made by the action of nitric acid on glycerin in the presence of sulphuric acid. It is extremely unstable and terribly explosive. A very dilute solution is used in medicine as a neurotic under the name of glonion.
nearby: situated near; as, the nearby towns.  Opposite of far away.
noninterchangeable: not able to be interchanged without changing the truth value.
Nutritious: Nourishing; promoting growth, or preventing decay; alimental.
Naticoid: Like or belonging to Natica, or the family Naticidæ.
Neozoic: More recent than the Paleozoic, -- that is, including the Mesozoic and Cenozoic.
Necrophagous: Of or pertaining to the Necrophaga; eating carrion. See Necrophagan.
Noncontagious: Not contagious; not catching; not communicable by contact.
Nonlimitation: Want of limitation; failure to limit.
Neglection: The state of being negligent; negligence.
Nonaged: Having the quality of nonage; being a minor; immature.
Narrowness: The condition or quality of being narrow.
nonimmune: Not having immunity; susceptible; likely to be affected with, if exposed.
Nobleness: The quality or state of being noble; greatness; dignity; magnanimity; elevation of mind, character, or station; nobility; grandeur; stateliness.
nonremittal: The act of failing to meet a financial obligation.
Neutrophil: One of a group of leukocytes whose granules stain only with neutral dyes; it is the chief phagocytic leukocyte in the circulating blood, comprising from 54% to 65% of the total number of leukocytes.
Necrologist: One who gives an account of deaths.
Nill: Shining sparks thrown off from melted brass.
Napoleonic: Of or pertaining to Napoleon I., or his family; resembling, or having the qualities of, Napoleon I.
Nomarchy: A province or territorial division of a kingdom, under the rule of a nomarch, as in modern Greece; a nome.
&Verbar;Nephralgia: Neuralgia of the kidneys; a disease characterized by pain in the region of the kidneys without any structural lesion of the latter.
Nostocaceae: A natural family of blue-green algae.
nuclear war: A war in which nuclear weapons are used by both sides.  As generally used, the term assumes major use of nuclear weapons by at least two opposing warring states.  As of 1999, no nuclear war has occurred.
Notorious: Generally known and talked of by the public; universally believed to be true; manifest to the world; evident; -- usually in an unfavorable sense; as, a notorious thief; a notorious crime or vice.
Note: A mark or token by which a thing may be known; a visible sign; a character; a distinctive mark or feature; a characteristic quality.
nosy: Offensively or intrusively curious; prying; nosey; as, he flipped through my letters in his nosy way.
Natter: To find fault; to be peevish.
Negatory: Expressing denial; belonging to negation; negative.
Neb: The nose; the snout; the mouth; the beak of a bird; a nib, as of a pen.
Neurotomist: One who skilled in or practices neurotomy.
Net: To produce or gain as clear profit; as, he netted a thousand dollars by the operation.
Nephrostome: The funnel-shaped opening of a nephridium into the body cavity.
New Years Day: the first day of a calendar year; the first day of January. Often colloquially abbreviated to New year's or new year.
Naturity: The quality or state of being produced by nature.
Nodule: A rounded mass or irregular shape; a little knot or lump.
Nonacquiescence: Refusal of acquiescence; failure to yield or comply.
nonretractable: not able to be drawn into the main body; -- of claws and other extensile parts of animals or objects; as, a bear's claws, unlike a cat's, are nonretractile.  Opposite of retractile.
Nimbleness: The quality of being nimble; lightness and quickness in motion; agility; swiftness.
Na\u00eff: Having a true natural luster without being cut; -- applied by jewelers to a precious stone.
Nosocomial: Of or pertaining to a hospital; as, nosocomial atmosphere.
Nativeness: The quality or state of being native.
&Verbar;Nidus: A nest: a repository for the eggs of birds, insects, etc.; a breeding place; esp., the place or substance where parasites or the germs of a disease effect lodgment or are developed.
Nobless: Dignity; greatness; noble birth or condition.
nonliterary: Characteristic of or appropriate to everyday language.
newsboy: A boy who distributes or sells newspapers.
neighbor: To adjoin; to border on; to be near to.
Neogen: An alloy resembling silver, and consisting chiefly of copper, zinc, and nickel, with small proportions of tin, aluminium, and bismuth.
Nubian: Of or pertaining to Nubia in Eastern Africa.
No: A refusal by use of the word no; a denial.
Nebulosity: The state or quality of being nebulous; cloudiness; haziness; mistiness; nebulousness.
Newfashioned: Made in a new form, or lately come into fashion.
Nepidae: A natural family of water scorpions.
Np: The chemical symbol for Neptunium, a transuranic element having atomic number 93.
nosecount: A count of the number of persons present or who are to be included in a group; as, get a nosecount of those who are planning to go; also, a periodic count of the population.
Nephrotomy: Extraction of stone from the kidney by cutting.
Nest: To put into a nest; to form a nest for.
&Verbar;Nematocalyx: One of a peculiar kind of cups, or calicles, found upon hydroids of the family Plumularidæ.  They contain nematocysts. See Plumularia.
Ness: A promontory; a cape; a headland.
Necrologic: Of or pertaining to necrology; of the nature of necrology; relating to, or giving, an account of the dead, or of deaths.
nemato-: A combining form from Gr. nh^ma, nh`matos, a thread.
Ni-hard: Cast iron to which nickel has been added to make it resist abrasion.
&Verbar;Neuropodium: The ventral lobe or branch of a parapodium.
Negotiability: The quality of being negotiable or transferable by indorsement.
Needily: In a needy condition or manner; necessarily.
&Verbar;Noumenon: The of itself unknown and unknowable rational object, or thing in itself, which is distinguished from the phenomenon through which it is apprehended by the senses, and by which it is interpreted and understood; -- so used in the philosophy of Kant and his followers.
Nobel prize: Prizes for the encouragement of men and women who work for the interests of humanity, established by the will of Alfred B. Nobel (1833-1896), the Swedish inventor of dynamite, who left his entire estate for this purpose.  They are awarded yearly for what is regarded as the most important work during the year in physics, chemistry, medicine or physiology, idealistic literature, and service in the interest of peace.  The prizes, averaging $40,000 each, were first awarded in 1901.  The monetary value of the awards have increased each year, to near one million U. S. dollars by the end of the 20th century.
no-hit: having no hits; characterized by one team scoring no hits; -- of a baseball game (or the pitching) in which a pitcher allows the opponent no hits; as, he pitched no-hit ball for seven innings.  A no-hit game is usually referred to as a no-hitter; as, His no-hit pitching.
Notion: Mental apprehension of whatever may be known or imagined; an idea; a conception; more properly, a general or universal conception, as distinguishable or definable by marks or notæ.
Novice: Like a novice; becoming a novice.
nonviolence: The theory, doctrine, or practice of peaceful resistance to a government by fasting or refusing to cooperate.
natica: Any one of numerous species of marine gastropods belonging to Natica, Lunatia, Neverita, and other allied genera (family Naticidæ.)  They burrow beneath the sand, or mud, and drill other shells.
Necrose: To affect with necrosis; to undergo necrosis.
Nogging: Rough brick masonry used to fill in the interstices of a wooden frame, in building.
non-discriminatory: Fair and unbiased; not discriminating; not biased against a particular group or type of person.
