Nicolaitan: One of certain corrupt persons in the early church at Ephesus, who are censured in Rev. ii. 6, 15.
Nuprin: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medicine used to relieve the pain of arthritis and as an analgesic and antipyretic; Advil and Motrin and Nuprin are trademarks of brands of ibuprofen tablets.
Nodosarine: Resembling in form or structure a foraminiferous shell of the genus Nodosaria.
nucleate: To form into a nucleus or multiple nuclei; as, raindrops may nucleate around silver iodide crystals.
Nosebag: A bag in which feed for a horse, ox, or the like, may be fastened under the nose by a string passing over the head.
Nasoturbinal: Connected with, or near, both the turbinal and the nasal bones; as, the nasoturbinal bone, made up of the uppermost lammelæ of the ethmoturbinal, and sometimes united with the nasal.
no-hitter: A game in which a pitcher allows the opposing team no hits.
Neologization: The act or process of neologizing.
Nasal: An elementary sound which is uttered through the nose, or through both the nose and the mouth simultaneously.
Neurocord: A cordlike organ composed of elastic fibers situated above the ventral nervous cord of annelids, like the earthworm.
Naval: Having to do with shipping; of or pertaining to ships or a navy; consisting of ships; as, naval forces, successes, stores, etc.
Noctilionid: A South American bat of the genus Noctilio, having cheek pouches and large incisor teeth.
Nose: To smell; to sniff; to scent.
Norwegium: A rare metallic element, of doubtful identification, said to occur in the copper-nickel of Norway.  Not recognized as an element (1999).
Newfangledness: Affectation of, or fondness for, novelty; vain or affected fashion or form.
nerve-racking: Extremely irritating to the nerves; stressful; trying; as, nerve-wracking noise.
Notch: To cut or make notches in; to indent; also, to score by notches; as, to notch a stick.
Nuthatch: Any one of several species of birds of the genus Sitta, as the European species (Sitta Europæa).  The white-breasted nuthatch (Sitta Carolinensis), the red-breasted nuthatch (Sitta Canadensis), the pygmy nuthatch (Sitta pygmæa), and others, are American.
Negotiation: The act or process of negotiating; a treating with another respecting sale or purchase. etc.
Nilotic: Of or pertaining to the river Nile; as, the Nilotic crocodile.
neuter: To render incapable of sexual reproduction; to remove or alter the sexual organs so as to make infertile; to alter; to fix; to desex; -- in male animals, to castrate; in female animals, to spay.
Nurser: One who nurses; a nurse; one who cherishes or encourages growth.
Neigh: The cry of a horse; a whinny.
nuclear family: A family consisting of parents and their children and grandparents of a marital partner.
Nodder: One who nods; a drowsy person.
nudnik: a pestiferous boring and dull person.
Noon: To take rest and refreshment at noon.
Nook: A narrow place formed by an angle in bodies or between bodies; a corner; a recess; a secluded retreat.
&Verbar;Nisan: The first month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, formerly answering nearly to the month of April, now to March, of the Christian calendar. See Abib.
niacin: A B vitamin (vitamin B5) essential for the normal function of the nervous system and the gastrointestinal tract.  Called also nicotinic acid and antipellagra vitamin.  Chemical formula C6H5NO2, chemically it is 3-pyridinecarboxylic acid.
numeracy: skill with numbers and mathematics; -- the skill with numbers analogous to literacy, the skill of reading.
Northerliness: The quality or state of being northerly; direction toward the north.
Nipper: One who, or that which, nips.
Nub: A jag, or snag; a knob; a protuberance; also, the point or gist, as of a story.
nuclear resonance: The resonance absorption of a gamma ray by a nucleus identical to the nucleus that emitted the gamma ray.
Neo-: A prefix meaning new, recent, late; and in chemistry designating specifically that variety of metameric hydrocarbons which, when the name was applied, had been recently classified, and in which at least one carbon atom is connected directly with four other carbon atoms; -- contrasted with normal and iso-; as, neopentane; the neoparaffins. Also used adjectively.
Necromantic: Of or pertaining to necromancy; performed by necromancy.
Nonimportation: Want or failure of importation; a not importing of commodities.
nori: A type of dried seaweed, pressed into sheets and used as a seasoning or as a wrapper for sushi.
Nonage: Time of life before a person becomes of age; legal immaturity; minority.
namedropper: Someone who pretends that famous people are his/her friends.  Someone who namedrops.
nymphalid: Any butterfly of the family Nymphalidae, consisting of medium to large butterflies found worldwide, typically having brightly colored wings and much-reduced nonfunctional forelegs carried folded on the breast.
Noiseless: Making, or causing, no noise or bustle; without noise; silent; as, the noiseless foot of time.
Nonconductor: A substance which does not conduct, that is, convey or transmit, heat, electricity, sound, vibration, or the like, or which transmits them with difficulty; an insulator; as, wool is a nonconductor of heat; glass and dry wood are nonconductors of electricity.
noncyclic: not occurring in cycles; not cyclic.  Opposite of cyclic.
Note paper: Writing paper, not exceeding in size, when folded once, five by eight inches.
Noncompliance: Neglect of compliance; failure to comply.
nickel-and-dime: Trivial; unimportant; petty; as, nickel-and-dime criticisms.
Nursing: Supplying or taking nourishment from, or as from, the breast; as, a nursing mother; a nursing infant.
Noah: A patriarch of Biblical history, in the time of the Deluge.
Norite: A granular crystalline rock consisting essentially of a triclinic feldspar (as labradorite) and hypersthene.
Nummulation: The arrangement of the red blood corpuscles in rouleaux, like piles of coins, as when a drop of human blood is examined under the microscope.
Nopalry: A plantation of the nopal for raising the cochineal insect.
&Verbar;Noli-me-tangere: Any plant of a genus of herbs (Impatiens) having capsules which, if touched when ripe, discharge their seeds. -- See Impatiens.
Nitrogen: A colorless nonmetallic element of atomic number 7, tasteless and odorless, comprising four fifths of the atmosphere by volume in the form of molecular nitrogen (N2).  It is chemically very inert in the free state, and as such is incapable of supporting life (hence the name azote still used by French chemists); but it forms many important compounds, such as ammonia, nitric acid, the cyanides, etc, and is a constituent of all organized living tissues, animal or vegetable.  Symbol N.  Atomic weight 14.007.  It was formerly regarded as a permanent noncondensible gas, but was liquefied in 1877 by Cailletet of Paris, and Pictet of Geneva, and boils at -195.8 ° C at atmospheric pressure.  Liquid nitrogen is used as a refrigerant to store delicate materials, such as bacteria, cells, and other biological materials.
neckless: lacking or apparently lacking a neck; -- of a garment; as, a neckless gown.
non-issue: the state of something that has outlived its relevance.
Numerate: To divide off and read according to the rules of numeration; as, to numerate a row of figures.
Needs: Of necessity; necessarily; indispensably; -- often with must, and equivalent to of need.
nonreturnable: That may not be returned for a refund; -- of purchased goods, or containers for purchased items; as, nonreturnable bottles.  Opposite of returnable.
Needy: Distressed by want of the means of living; very poor; indigent; necessitous.
Number: That which admits of being counted or reckoned; a unit, or an aggregate of units; a numerable aggregate or collection of individuals; an assemblage made up of distinct things expressible by figures.
Nasalization: The act of nasalizing, or the state of being nasalized.
Nudibranch: Of or pertaining to the Nudibranchiata.
Nativity: The coming into life or into the world; birth; also, the circumstances attending birth, as time, place, manner, etc.
nonlinear: Not depictable graphically as a straight line; not changing by a constant amount for each unit of time, distance, or other independent variable.  Opposite of linear.
Norther: A wind from the north; esp., a strong and cold north wind in Texas and the vicinity of the Gulf of Mexico.
Novenary: The number of nine units; nine, collectively.
Ninety: The sum of nine times ten; the number greater by a unit than eighty-nine; ninety units or objects.
Nowhere: Not anywhere; not in any place or state; as, the book is nowhere to be found.
Napiers bones: A set of rods, made of bone or other material, each divided into nine spaces, and containing the numbers of a column of the multiplication table; -- a contrivance of Baron Napier, the inventor of logarithms, for facilitating the operations of multiplication and division.
Nummulitic: Of, like, composed of, containing, nummulites; as, nummulitic beds.
Notice: To observe; to see; to mark; to take note of; to heed; to pay attention to.
Nasutness: Quickness of scent; hence, nice discernment; acuteness.
Noachian: Of or pertaining to the patriarch Noah, or to his time.
Nazarene: A native or inhabitant of Nazareth; -- a term of contempt applied to Christ and the early Christians.
&Verbar;Narcosis: Privation of sense or consciousness, due to a narcotic.
nuclear warhead: The warhead of a missile containing an atom bomb or hydrogen bomb.
Neog\u00e6an: Of or pertaining to the New World, or Western Hemisphere.
neocortical: Of or pertaining to the neocortex.
no-no: Something improper, unethical, inadvisable, or illegal; as, salt is a no-no for someone after a heart attack.
Nucleolated: Having a nucleole, or second inner nucleus.
Nitrated: Combined, or impregnated, with nitric acid, or some of its compounds.
nymphomania: An uncontrollable excessive sexual desire in women, constituting a true disease.
Northwester: A storm or gale from the northwest; a strong northwest wind.
nuclear reaction: A process that alters the energy or structure or composition of an atomic nucleus.
Numismatography: A treatise on, or description of, coins and medals.
Nutritial: Pertaining to, or connected with, nutrition; nutritious.
nosegay: A bunch of odorous and showy flowers; a bouquet; a posy.
nuclear fission: A nuclear reaction in which a heavy atomic nucleus splits into smaller nuclei with the simultaneous release of energy.
Naphthalize: To mingle, saturate, or impregnate, with naphtha.
&Verbar;Nemathecium: A peculiar kind of fructification on certain red algæ, consisting of an external mass of filaments at length separating into tetraspores.
nothings: inconsequential conversation; as, they traded a few nothings as they parted.
Norfolk jacket: A kind of loose-fitting plaited jacket, having a loose belt.
Nonacquaintance: Want of acquaintance; the state of being unacquainted.
Nodical: Of or pertaining to the nodes; from a node to the same node again; as, the nodical revolutions of the moon.
no-good: without merit; useless; as, the car was a no-good piece of junk.
Nagging: Fault-finding; teasing; persistently annoying; as, a nagging toothache.
&Verbar;Not\u00e6um: The back or upper surface, as of a bird.
Nibbler: One who, or that which, nibbles.
nonviolent: peacefully resistant in response to injustice; not using violence; -- used of protests and demonstrations; as, nonviolent resistance.  Opposite of violent.
Nesslerize: To treat or test, as a liquid, with a solution of mercuric iodide in potassium iodide and potassium hydroxide, which is called Nessler's solution or Nessler's test, and is used to detect the presence of ammonia.
normative: relating to or dealing with norms; as, normative discipline; normative samples.
Naturist: One who believes in, or conforms to, the theory of naturism.
Nectarial: Of or pertaining to the nectary of a plant.
Nominee: A person named, or designated, by another, to any office, duty, or position; one nominated, or proposed, by others for office or for election to office.  One remains a nominee until one has been elected or has assumed the office.
Noahs ark: The ship built by Noah according to God's command, as related in the bible.
Nobley: The body of nobles; the nobility.
nine: Eight and one more; one less than ten; as, nine miles.
Noria: A large water wheel, turned by the action of a stream against its floats, and carrying at its circumference buckets, by which water is raised and discharged into a trough; used in Arabia, China, and elsewhere for irrigating land; a Persian wheel.
Nestorian: Of or relating to the Nestorians.
Neurosensiferous: Pertaining to, or forming, both nerves and sense organs.
Naturism: The belief or doctrine that attributes everything to nature as a sanative agent.
Nidulation: The time of remaining in the nest.
nippy: Pleasantly cold and invigorating; -- of weather conditions.
nogoodnik: A worthless, disreputable, or malicious person.
Norn: Any one of the three Fates, Past, Present, and Future.  Their names were Urd, Verdandi, and Skuld.  They are identified with the Anglo-Saxon Wyrd, and are similar to the Greek Moirae and Roman Parcae.
Nyctitropic: Turning or bending at night into special positions.
Nonrendition: Neglect of rendition; the not rendering what is due.
Neophyte: A new convert or proselyte; -- a name given by the early Christians, and still given by the Roman Catholics, to such as have recently embraced the Christian faith, and been admitted to baptism, esp. to converts from heathenism or Judaism.
Numismatic: Of or pertaining to coins; relating to the science of coins or medals.
Narratory: Giving an account of events; narrative; as, narratory letters.
Nehushtan: A thing of brass; -- the name under which the Israelites worshiped the brazen serpent made by Moses.
Napping: The act or process of raising a nap, as on cloth.
never-ending: endless or seemingly endless; as, the never-ending search for happiness.
&Verbar;Neuroglia: The delicate connective tissue framework which supports the nervous matter and blood vessels of the brain and spinal cord; called also Kölliker's reticulum.  It is composed of cells which are not neurons.   Once thought to serve merely a supporting funciton, they are now believed to have important metablolic functions.  Among them are the astrocytes, ependymal cells, oligodendroglia cells, and microglia cells.
narrable: Capable of being narrated or told.
Nettle: To fret or sting; to irritate or vex; to cause to experience sensations of displeasure or uneasiness not amounting to violent anger.
Navvy: Originally, a laborer on canals for internal navigation; hence, a laborer on other public works, as in building railroads, embankments, etc.
&Verbar;Nuraghe: One of the prehistoric towerlike structures found in Sardinia.
Numbfish: The torpedo, which numbs by the electric shocks which it gives.
Nero: A Roman emperor notorious for debauchery and barbarous cruelty; hence, any profligate and cruel ruler or merciless tyrant.
Nullipore: A name for certain crustaceous marine algæ which secrete carbonate of lime on their surface, and were formerly thought to be of animal nature.  They are now considered corallines of the genera Melobesia and Lithothamnion.
nonindustrial: not industrial; -- used of societies.  Opposite of industrial and industrialized.
&Verbar;Notobranchiata: A division of nudibranchiate mollusks having gills upon the back.
&Verbar;Napu: A very small chevrotain (Tragulus Javanicus), native of Java. It is about the size of a hare, and is noted for its agility in leaping. Called also Java musk deer, pygmy musk deer, and deerlet.
Nicotinic: Pertaining to, or derived from, nicotine; nicotic; -- used specifically to designate an acid related to pyridine, obtained by the oxidation of nicotine, and called nicotinic acid.
Niggard: To act the niggard toward; to be niggardly.
Nugify: To render trifling or futile; to make silly.
Nonplus: To puzzle; to confound; to perplex; to cause to stop by embarrassment.
&Verbar;Nisi: Unless; if not; -- used mostly in law.
&Verbar;Ne Temere: A decree of the Congregation of the Council declaring invalid [so far as the laws of the Roman Catholic Church are concerned] any marriage of a Roman Catholic, or of a person who has ever been a Roman Catholic, if not contracted before a duty qualified priest (or the bishop of the diocese) and at least two witnesses.  The decree was issued Aug. 2, 1907, and took effect on Easter Apr. 19, 1908. The decree by its terms does not affect mixed marriages (those between Roman Catholics and persons of another faith) in Germany.
nystatin: An antifungal antibiotic, extracted from fermentation broths of the soil actinomycete Streptomyces noursei and other actinomycetes; called also fungicidin.  It is a polyene macrolide antibiotic, and consists of several related components.  Component nystatin A1 has formula C47H75NO17.
&Verbar;Neuron: The brain and spinal cord; the cerebro-spinal axis; myelencephalon.
nonproductive: not directly productive; as, nonproductive labor.
nifty: Very good; excellent; -- an informal term meaning about the same as groovy, sense 1.
Nomocracy: Government in accordance with a system of law.
nemertine: Any of an order (Nemertina) of soft unsegmented marine worms having an eversible threadlike proboscis and the ability to stretch and contract.
&Verbar;Nematoidea: A phylum of worms, having a long, round, and generally smooth body; the roundworms.  Called also Nematodea, and more commonly Nematoda.  Formerly, it was classed as a taxonomic order.
nonnative: not being or composed of aborigines; as, the nonnative population of South Africa.  Opposite of native.
Neo-Greek: A member of a body of French painters (F. les néo-Grecs) of the middle 19th century.  The term is rather one applied by outsiders to certain artists of grave and refined style, such as Hamon and Aubert, than a name adopted by the artists themselves.
nekton: The aggregate of actively swimming animals in a body of water ranging from microscopic organisms to whales.
nuclear reactor: Any of several devices that maintain and control a sustained nuclear fission chain reaction, for the production of energy, heat, or artificial elements, or for research purposes.  The main fuel sustaining the reaction and consumed by the process is typically uranium or plutonium.
Nympholeptic: Under the influence of nympholepsy; ecstatic; frenzied.
&Verbar;Nototherium: An extinct genus of gigantic herbivorous marsupials, found in the Pliocene formation of Australia.
Negotious: Very busy; attentive to business; active.
Northeastern: Of or pertaining to the northeast; northeasterly.
Nidgery: A trifle; a piece of foolery.
Non-: A prefix used in the sense of not; un-; in-; as in nonattention, or non-attention, nonconformity, nonmetallic, nonsuit.
Naught: Of no value or account; worthless; bad; useless.
&Verbar;Nemertina: An order of helminths usually having a long, slender, smooth, often bright-colored body, covered with minute vibrating cilia; -- called also Nemertea, Nemertida, and Rhynchocœla.
nonmonotonic: not monotonic; -- of relations between variables.  Opposite of monotonic.
navigational: of or pertaining to navigation; used in navigation; as, navigational aids.
nuclear magnetic resonance: The specific absorption and re-emission of electromagnetic radiation at characteristic wavelengths by atomic nuclei in a magnetic field.  It is abbreviated NMR.  The wavelength of the radiation absorbed depends on the type of nucleus, the intensity of the magnetic field, and the local chemical environment in which the nucleus resides.  It is the latter effect (called the chemical shift), by which atoms of specific elements in different chemical compounds show a different resonance frequency, which gives rise to the greatest utility of this phenomenon in analyzing the chemical structure of substances.  Similar effects of the chemical environment permit the discrimination of different types of living tissue by virtue of their different chemical composition, thus permitting utilization of the phenomenon in medical diagnostic instruments, especially for magnetic resonance imaging.
Nutgall: A more or less round gall resembling a nut, esp. one of those produced on the oak and used in the arts. See Gall, Gallnut.
Neo-Hellenism: Hellenism as surviving or revival in modern times; the practice or pursuit of ancient Greek ideals in modern life, art, or literature, as in the Renaissance.
&Verbar;Nauplius: A crustacean larva having three pairs of locomotive organs (corresponding to the antennules, antennæ, and mandibles), a median eye, and little or no segmentation of the body.
Newness: The quality or state of being new; as, the newness of a system; the newness of a scene; newness of life.
Northwestern: Of, pertaining to, or being in, the northwest; in a direction toward the northwest; coming from the northwest; northwesterly; as, a northwestern course.
Nonattendance: A failure to attend; omission of attendance; nonappearance.
&Verbar;Nunc dimittis: The song of Simeon (Luke ii. 29-32), used in the ritual of many churches.  It begins with these words in the Vulgate.
Nona: The Fate who spins the thread of life; counterpart of Greek Clotho.
Nonillion: According to the French and American notation, a thousand octillions, or a unit with thirty ciphers annexed; according to the English notation, a million octillions, or a unit with fifty-four ciphers annexed. See the Note under Numeration.
noncellular: Not made up of or divided into cells.  Opposite of cellular.
Nina: A goddess of the watery deep and daughter of Ea.
Nine: The number greater than eight by a unit; nine units or objects.
Nunciate: One who announces; a messenger; a nuncio.
&Verbar;Nabk: The edible berries of the Zizyphys Lotus, a tree of Northern Africa, and Southwestern Europe.
Nonrecurring: Nonrecurrent; as, the costs of a layoff are considered as a nonrecurring expense.
Nasality: The quality or state of being nasal.
Numerative: Of or pertaining to numeration; as, a numerative system.
Noggen: Made of hemp; hence, hard; rough; harsh.
Numismatist: One skilled in numismatics; a numismatologist.
Nondeciduate: Characterized by the absence of a decidua; indeciduate.
netted: resembing a net or a web.
&Verbar;Nemathelminthes: An order of helminths, including the Nematoidea and Gordiacea; the roundworms.
Nonuser: A not using; failure to use.
nutritionist: a specialist in the study of nutrition.
nymphal: Of or pertaining to a nymph or nymphs; nymphean.
Notodontian: Any one of several species of bombycid moths belonging to Notodonta, Nerice, and allied genera. The caterpillar of these moths has a hump, or spine, on its back.
Nonresident: A nonresident person; one who does not reside in the State or jurisdiction.
Newel: The upright post about which the steps of a circular staircase wind; hence, in stairs having straight flights, the principal post at the foot of a staircase, or the secondary ones at the landings.  Also called newel post.  See Hollow newel, under Hollow.
Nominative: Giving a name; naming; designating; -- said of that case or form of a noun which stands as the subject of a finite verb.
&Verbar;Netsuke: In Japanese costume and decorative art, a small object carved in wood, ivory, bone, or horn, or wrought in metal, and pierced with holes for cords by which it is connected, for convenience, with the inro, the smoking pouch (tabako-ire), and similar objects carried in the girdle. It is now much used on purses sold in Europe and America.
&Verbar;Nolo contendere: A plea, by the defendant, in a criminal prosecution, which, without admitting guilt, subjects him to all the consequences of a plea of guilty.
Nephropsidae: A natural family in some classifications coextensive with the Homaridae.
Nitrile: Any one of a series of compounds bearing the cyanide radical (-CN); particularly, one of those cyanides of alcohol radicals which, by boiling with acids or alkalies, produce a carboxyl acid, with the elimination of the nitrogen as ammonia.
northbound: Moving toward the north; as, northbound traffic.
Nonconcur: To dissent or refuse to concur.
Nemean: Of or pertaining to Nemea, in Argolis, where the ancient Greeks celebrated games, and Hercules killed a lion.
Neckweed: An American annual weed (veronica peregrina), with small white flowers and a roundish pod.
Noblewoman: A female of noble rank; a peeress.
Neuroskeleton: The deep-seated parts of the vertebrate skeleton which are in relation with the nervous axis and locomotion.
Necrobiotic: Of or pertaining to necrobiosis; as, a necrobiotic metamorphosis.
&Verbar;Nucula: A genus of small marine bivalve shells, having a pearly interior.
nauch: an intricate traditional dance in India performed by professional dancing girls.
Nevermore: Never again; at no time hereafter.
nonrepresentational: not intended to realistically represent a physical object; -- of visual art work.  Opposite of representational.
nonreversible: Not reversible or capable of having either side out; -- used mostly of clothing.  Opposite of reversible.
Nitratine: A mineral occurring in transparent crystals, usually of a white, sometimes of a reddish gray, or lemon-yellow, color; native sodium nitrate. It is used in making nitric acid and for manure. Called also soda niter.
Nur: A hard knot in wood; also, a hard knob of wood used by boys in playing hockey.
Nul: No; not any; as, nul disseizin; nul tort.
Nitranilic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex organic acid produced as a white crystalline substance by the action of nitrous acid on hydroquinone.
Nascency: State of being nascent; birth; beginning; origin.
Nowadays: In these days; at the present time.
Nickelic: Pertaining to, or containing, nickel; specifically, designating compounds in which, as contrasted with the nickelous compounds, the metal has a higher valence; as nickelic oxide.
Nonconformist: One who does not conform to an established church; especially, one who does not conform to the established church of England; a dissenter.
nightcrawler: A terrestrial worm that burrows into and helps aerate soil; an earthworm.  It often surfaces when the ground is cool or wet, and is used as bait by anglers.  The term is used mostly in the northern and western U. S.
Nurse: To nourish; to cherish; to foster
Nil: A special value for a variable used in certain computer languages to mean no assigned value, to be distinguished from the value zero.
Nim: To take; to steal; to filch.
Nib: To furnish with a nib; to point; to mend the point of; as, to nib a pen.
Nix: One of a class of water spirits, commonly described as of a mischievous disposition.
Naphthazarin: A dyestuff, resembling alizarin, obtained from naphthoquinone as a red crystalline substance with a bright green, metallic luster; -- called also naphthalizarin.
Nit: The egg of a louse or other small insect.
narcist: Someone in love with themselves; a narcissist.
Neurapophysial: Of or pertaining to a neurapophysis.
Namesake: One that has the same name as another; especially, one called after, or named out of regard to, another.
Nightcap: A cap worn in bed to protect the head, or in undress.
Nidulite: A Silurian fossil, formerly supposed to consist of eggs.
Nutrication: The act or manner of feeding.
Neurologist: One who is versed in neurology; also, one skilled in the treatment of nervous diseases.
nebulated: Clouded with indistinct color markings, as an animal.
Neuroskeletal: Of or pertaining to the neuroskeleton.
Nuclear weapon: A weapon of great explosive power, such as an atomic bomb or a hydrogen bomb, which depends for most of its explosive power on the release of energy from within atomic nuclei by a nuclear reaction.  A fission weapon or a fusion weapon.  The term includes atomic shells for cannon.
Nandou: Any one of three species of South American ostriches of the genera Rhea and Pterocnemia, especially the smallest, Pterocnemia pennata (formerly Rhea Americana), called also the common rhea.  They are tall fast-running flightless birds similar to ostriches but three-toed, found from Peru to the Straits of Magellan.  See Rhea.
Nailery: A factory where nails are made.
Nosophen: An iodine compound obtained as a yellowish gray, odorless, tasteless powder by the action of iodine on phenolphthalein.
Notable: A person, or thing, of distinction.
Novatianism: The doctrines or principles of the Novatians.
Noonday: Of or pertaining to midday; meridional; as, the noonday heat; only mad dogs and Englishmen go out in the noonday sun.
Nuzzle: To work with the nose, like a swine in the mud.
Nunnation: The pronunciation of n at the end of words.
Noctuid: Any one of numerous moths of the family Noctuidæ, or Noctuælitæ, as the cutworm moths, and armyworm moths; -- so called because they fly at night.
nonmechanistic: not determined by a mechanical process; partly resulting from a creative process.
Neckerchief: A kerchief for the neck; -- called also neck handkerchief.
Navarino: The name of a naval battle in the War of Greek Independence (1827), at which the Turkish and Egyptian fleet was defeated by the allied fleet.
Neocriticism: The form of Neo-Kantianism developed by French idealists, following C. Renouvier.  It rejects the noumena of Kant, restricting knowledge to phenomena as constituted by a priori categories.
Notching: The act of making notches; the act of cutting into small hollows.
Nitrolic: Of, derived from, or designating, a nitrol; as, a nitrolic acid.
Niobe: The daughter of Tantalus, and wife of Amphion, king of Thebes.  Her pride in her children provoked Apollo and Diana, who slew them all.  Niobe herself was changed by the gods into stone.
Nutrient: Any substance which has nutritious qualities, i. e., which nourishes or promotes growth; a nutriment.
Nucleated: Having a nucleus; nucleate; as, nucleated cells.
Nephthys: The goddess associated with ritual of the dead; sister of Geb and Nut; wife of Set.
Nook-shotten: Full of nooks, angles, or corners.
Nobility: The quality or state of being noble; superiority of mind or of character; commanding excellence; eminence.
Naso-: A combining form denoting pertaining to the nose, or connected with the nose; as, nasofrontal.
Nitrogenous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, nitrogen; as, a nitrogenous principle; nitrogenous compounds.
Noematic: Of or pertaining to the understanding.
Nauheim treatment: Orig., a method of therapeutic treatment administered, esp. for chronic diseases of the curculatory system, at Bad Nauheim, Germany, by G. Schott, consisting in baths in the natural mineral waters of that place, which are charged with carbonic acid, and the use of a graduated course of rest, physical exercises, massage, etc.; hence, any similar treatment using waters artificially charged with the essential ingredients of the natural mineral waters of Bad Nauheim.  Hence, Nauheim bath, etc.
Normanism: A Norman idiom; a custom or expression peculiar to the Normans.
nickelodeon: A place of entertainment, as for moving picture exhibition, charging a fee or admission price of five cents.
Nonunionist: One who does not belong, or refuses to belong, to a trades union.
&Verbar;Ne exeat: A writ to restrain a person from leaving the country, or the jurisdiction of the court.  The writ was originally applicable to purposes of state, but is now an ordinary process of courts of equity, resorted to for the purpose of obtaining bail, or security to abide a decree.
north-polar: Of or pertaining to the North Pole; at or near the north pole; characteristic of the north pole.
nacho: A tortilla chip topped with cheese and often chili-pepper or beans and then broiled; -- eaten as a snack or light meal.
Nimbiferous: Serving to bring clouds or stormy weather.
Nias: A young hawk; an eyas; hence, an unsophisticated person.
Necessitied: In a state of want; necessitous.
Neither: Not either; generally used to introduce the first of two or more coördinate clauses of which those that follow begin with nor.
noninstitutionalized: not committed to an institution; -- op people.  Opposite of institutionalized.
nuclear energy: Energy derived from nuclear reactions; -- used at present especially of electrical power generated in atomic reactors, but encompassing also fusion energy.
Nurseryman: One who cultivates or keeps a nursery, or place for rearing trees, etc.
Neoplatonic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, Neoplatonism or the Neoplatonists.
Neocene: More recent than the Eocene, that is, including both the Miocene and Pliocene divisions of the Tertiary.
nucleoside: A type of molecule found in all living organisms, present mostly in chemically combined form as a component of nucleic acids, and also in smaller amounts in free form, consisting of a pentose sugar bound to a purine or pyrimidine base; two types of nucleoside, ribonucleoside and deoxyribonucleoside, are present.  The most common bases present in nucleosides are adenine, cytosine, uracil, guanine, and thymine, and to a lesser extent hypoxanthine and other bases are found.  The most commmon ribonucleosides composed from these bases are called adenosine, cytidine, uridine, and guanosine.  The forms esterified with orthophosphoric at the 5-position of the pentose are called nucleotides.  The nucleotides form the monomer units which are combined into DNA and RNA, which carry the genetic information required for reproduction in all known organisms.
&Verbar;Nez Perc\u00e9s: A tribe of Indians, in the late 1800's mostly inhabiting Idaho.  They were involved under Chief Joseph, in the last major battle of the Indian wars, attempting to resist being moved to a reservation.
nincompoop: A fool; a silly or stupid person.
Neritidae: A natural family comprising the neritids.
Niter: A white crystalline semitransparent salt; potassium nitrate; saltpeter. See Saltpeter.
noncommital: Not expressing a preference; as, although favoring European unity he was noncommittal about the form it should take.
&Verbar;Nicagua: The laughing falcon. See under laughing.
&Verbar;Noyade: A drowning of many persons at once, -- a method of execution practiced at Nantes in France during the Reign of Terror, by Jean Baptiste Carrier.
Nubile: Of an age suitable for marriage; marriageable.
Nonphotobiotic: Capable of living without light; as, nonphotobiotic plant cells, or cells which habitually live in darkness.
Negatively: In a negative manner; with or by denial.
Negativeness: The quality or state of being negative.
Nymphales: Same as Nymphalidae, an extensive family of butterflies including the nymphs, the satyrs, the monarchs, the heliconias, and others; -- called also brush-footed butterflies.
Nitrosyl: The radical -NO, called also the nitroso group.  The term is sometimes loosely used to designate certain nitro compounds; as, nitrosyl sulphuric acid.  Used also adjectively.
Nervure: One of the nerves of leaves.
Numididae: A subfamily of birds including the guinea fowl and related birds of Africa and Madagascar.
Niopo: A kind of snuff prepared by the natives of Venezuela from the roasted seeds of a leguminous tree (Piptadenia peregrina), thence called niopo tree.
Nigerian: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of the country Nigeria; as, The Nigerian capital used to be Lagos.
Nitriferous: Bearing niter; yielding, or containing, niter.
Noctilucin: A fatlike substance in certain marine animals, to which they owe their phosphorescent properties.
Nationalization: The act of nationalizing, or the state of being nationalized.
newborn: A baby recently born, usually less than one month old; a neonate.
Nebular: Of or pertaining to nebulæ; of the nature of, or resembling, a nebula.
&Verbar;Ne plus ultra: The uttermost point to which one can go or attain; hence, the summit of achievement; the highest point or degree; the acme.
numinous: Evincing the presence of a deity; as, a numinous wood; the most numinous moment in the Mass.
Neoimpressionism: A theory or practice which is a further development, on more rigorously scientific lines, of the theory and practice of Impressionism, originated by George Seurat (1859-91), and carried on by Paul Signac (1863- -) and others.  Its method is marked by the laying of pure primary colors in minute dots upon a white ground, any given line being produced by a variation in the proportionate quantity of the primary colors employed.  This method is also known as Pointillism (stippling).
nest egg: An egg left in the nest to prevent the hen from forsaking it, and to induce her to lay more in the same place.
Nearctic: Of or pertaining to a region of the earth's surface including all of temperate and arctic North America and Greenland. In the geographical distribution of animals, this region is marked off as the habitat certain species.
noncollapsable: not able to be folded into a compact form.  Opposite of collapsible.
Neoclassic: Belonging to, or designating, the modern revival or adaptation of classical, esp. Greco-Roman, style, taste and manner of work in architecture, arts, literature, etc.
napa: A plant (Brassica rapa pekinensis) with an elongated celerylike head of broadstalked leaves used as a vegetable in east Asia; called also Chinese cabbage.
N: A measure of space equal to half an M (or em); an en.
North-American: of or pertaining to or characteristic of the continent or countries of North America and their peoples.
Neo-Kantianism: The philosophy of modern thinkers who follow Kant in his general theory of knowledge, esp. of a group of German philosophers including F. A. Lange, H. Cohen, Paul Natorp, and others.
Navigability: The quality or condition of being navigable; navigableness.
Neomorph: A structure, part, or organ developed independently, that is, not derived from a similar structure, part, or organ, in a preexisting form.
next-to-last: next preceding the last; as, the figures in the next-to-last column.
Nitrobacter: A genus of rod-shaped soil bacteria.
Niagara: A river flowing from Lake Erie into Lake Ontario, which forms the boundary between Ontario and New York.
needlebush: A shrub (Hakea lissosperma) of eastern Australia, with pungent rigid needle-shaped leaves and white flowers.
Negritic: Of or pertaining to negroes; composed of negroes.
Nondeposition: A failure to deposit or throw down.
Nonpreparation: Neglect or failure to prepare; want of preparation.
Night-eyed: Capable of seeing at night; sharp-eyed.
Nonet: A composition for nine instruments, rarely for nine voices.
Nigrification: The act or process of making black.
noreaster: a storm blowing from the northeast; -- a term used especially in the northeastern region of the United States.
Nation: A part, or division, of the people of the earth, distinguished from the rest by common descent, language, or institutions; a race; a stock.
Nihilistic: Of, pertaining to, or characterized by, nihilism.
neencephalon: The most recently evolved part of the brain of higher animals.  It includes the cerebral cortex and related structures.
Nosology: A systematic arrangement, or classification, of diseases.
Nidification: The act or process of building a nest.
noncarbonated: not having supersaturated carbon dioxide in solution; not carbonated; -- of beverages.
Neo-Hegelianism: The philosophy of a school of British and American idealists who follow Hegel in dialectical or logical method and in the general outcome of their doctrine.  The founders and leaders of Neo-Hegelianism include: in England, T. H. Green (1836-1882); in Scotland, J. Caird (1820-98) and E. Caird (1835-1908); in the United States, W. T. Harris (1835-1909) and Josiah Royce (1855- -).
Noemics: The science of the understanding; intellectual science.
Nerved: Having nerves of a special character; as, weak-nerved.
nondeductible: not allowable as a tax deduction; as, political contributions are nondeductible.  Opposite of deductible.
Ni-resist: Cast iron consisting of graphite in a matrix of austenite.
nickname: A name given in affectionate familiarity, sportive familiarity, contempt, or derision; a familiar or an opprobrious appellation; as, Nicholas's nickname is Nick.
Null: One of the beads in nulled work.
Nascal: A kind of pessary of medicated wool or cotton, formerly used.
Namer: One who names, or calls by name.
nonwashable: not washable; damaged by washing; -- used mostly of clothing, especially clothing that must be cleaned by a dry-cleaning process.  Opposite of washable.
Nitrous: Of, pertaining to, or containing, niter; of the quality of niter, or resembling it.
named: given or having a specified name; as, an actor named Harold Lloyd; a building in Cardiff named the Temple of Peace.  Contrasted to unnamed.
Nonmetal: Any one of the set of elements which, as contrasted with the metals, possess, produce, or receive, acid rather than basic properties; a metalloid; as, oxygen, sulphur, and chlorine are nonmetals.
Nighly: In a near relation in place, time, degree, etc.; within a little; almost.
Noule: The top of the head; the head or noll.
Nationally: In a national manner or way; as a nation.
Nonobedience: Neglect of obedience; failure to obey.
Numb: To make numb; to deprive of the power of sensation or motion; to render senseless or inert; to deaden; to benumb; to stupefy.
Neptunian: One who adopts the Neptunian theory.
Nooning: A rest at noon; a repast at noon.
Neologism: The introduction of new words, or the use of old words in a new sense.
Nursemaid: A girl or woman employed to attend and care for children.
Nasofrontal: Of or pertaining to the nose and the front of the head; as, the embryonic nasofrontal process which forms the anterior boundary of the mouth.
Noctograph: A kind of writing frame for the blind.
nationalist: One who advocates national unity and independence; -- as, for example, one of a party favoring Irish independence before 1918.
Neologist: One who introduces new words or new senses of old words into a language.
Nip: A seizing or closing in upon; a pinching; as, in the northern seas, the nip of masses of ice.
Ninetieth: The quotient of a unit divided by ninety; one of ninety equal parts of anything.
nonhereditary: Not inheritable through genetic transmission.  Opposite of inheritable, and heritable.
&Verbar;Nawab: A deputy ruler or viceroy in India; also, a title given by courtesy to other persons of high rank in the East.
noninterference: a foreign policy of staying out of other countries' disputes; nonintervention.
&Verbar;Neuroma: A tumor developed on, or connected with, a nerve, esp. one consisting of new-formed nerve fibers.
nonabsorbent: not capable of absorbing or soaking up (liquids).  Opposite of absorbent.
Nape: The back part of the neck.
newsletter: A circular letter, written or printed for the purpose of disseminating news.  This was the name given to the earliest English newspapers.
Nipplewort: A yellow-flowered composite herb (Lampsana communis), formerly used as an external application to the nipples of women; -- called also dock-cress.
Nauruan: Of or pertaining to Nauru; as, Nauruan artifacts.
Noctivagation: A roving or going about in the night.
Nitrogenize: To combine, or impregnate, with nitrogen or its compounds.
Neathouse: A building for the shelter of neat cattle.
Numerosity: The state of being numerous; numerousness.
Nothing: In no degree; not at all; in no wise.
Nonconformity: Neglect or failure of conformity; especially, in England, the neglect or refusal to unite with the established church in its rites and modes of worship.
Novilunar: Of or pertaining to the new moon.
night-sight: The ability to see in reduced illumination (as in moonlight); night vision.
Node: A knot, a knob; a protuberance; a swelling.
Nectar: The drink of the gods (as ambrosia was their food); hence, any delicious or inspiring beverage.
noncom: A noncommissioned officer; a military officer appointed from enlisted personnel.
Notwithstanding: Nevertheless; however; although; as, I shall go, notwithstanding it rains.
Northerner: One born or living in the north.
Neossine: The substance constituting the edible bird's nest.
Nucamentaceous: Like a nut either in structure or in being indehiscent; bearing one-seeded nutlike fruits.
&Verbar;Neurasthenia: A condition of nervous debility supposed to be dependent upon impairment in the functions of the spinal cord.
Nemoral: Of or pertaining to a wood or grove.
Narrowly: With little breadth; in a narrow manner.
nonequivalent: Not equal or interchangeable in value, quantity, or significance.
Noncondensing: Not condensing; discharging the steam from the cylinder at a pressure nearly equal to or above that of the atmosphere and not into a condenser.
Necrotomy: The dissection of dead bodies; also, excision of necrosed bone.
nonparticipation: withdrawing from the activities of a group.
No-mans land: A space amidships used to keep blocks, ropes, etc.; a space on a ship belonging to no one in particular to care for.
Natty: Neatly dressed; smart; trim; tidy; spruce.
Neckcloth: A piece of any fabric worn around the neck.
neuropharmacologic: acting upon or influencing nervous functions; -- of chemical substances.
Nuclear: of, pertaining to, or using nuclear weapons; a nuclear exchange, i.e. a reciprocal bombardment by nuclear weapons..
Norman: A native or inhabitant of Normandy; originally, one of the Northmen or Scandinavians who conquered Normandy in the 10th century; afterwards, one of the mixed (Norman-French) race which conquered England, under William the Conqueror.
Nankeen: A species of cloth, of a firm texture, originally brought from China, made of a species of cotton (Gossypium religiosum) that is naturally of a brownish yellow color quite indestructible and permanent.
Neatly: In a neat manner; tidily; tastefully.
normality: Conformity with the norm; the state of being normal; the normal condition.
nuclear explosion: The explosion of an atomic bomb or atomic device; -- sometimes also used of fusion-powered explosions.
Neodamode: In ancient Sparta, one of those Helots who were freed by the state in reward for military service.
Napkin: A little towel, made of cloth or paper, esp. one for wiping the fingers and mouth at table.
Natchez: A tribe of Indians who formerly lived near the site of the city of Natchez, Mississippi.  In 1729 they were subdued by the French; the survivors joined the Creek Confederacy.
Noonstead: The position of the sun at noon.
Nymphaeaceae: A natural family of dicot aquatic plants.
Nicene: Of or pertaining to Nice, a town of Asia Minor, or to the ecumenical council held there a. d. 325.
nonpregnant: not pregnant; as, a drug approved only for use in nonpregnant females.  Opposite of pregnant.
nonextant: No longer existing; inaccessible through loss or destruction.
northland: any region lying in or toward the north.
Nomenclatural: Pertaining or according to a nomenclature.
Nonmalignant: Not malignant, as a disease; -- used especially of tumors; as, a nonmalignant growth on the liver.
Nugation: The act or practice of trifling.
Narcotize: To imbue with, or subject to the influence of, a narcotic; to put into a state of narcosis.
nephrolithic: Of or pertaining to kidney stones, or renal calculi.
&Verbar;Nudum pactum: A bare, naked contract, without any consideration and therefore unenforceable in a court of law.
Narrowing: The act of contracting, or of making or becoming less in breadth or extent.
nematocide: A substance that kills nematodes, especially one used in medicine or to kill plant pathogens.
notecase: A case for holding paper money; a wallet.
Nye: A brood or flock of pheasants.
Nightshade: A common name of many species of the genus Solanum, given esp. to the Solanum nigrum, or black nightshade, a low, branching weed with small white flowers and black berries reputed to be poisonous.
&Verbar;Necrobiosis: The death of a part of an organism by molecular disintegration and without loss of continuity, as in the processes of degeneration and atrophy; a normal dying out of cells in a tissue, in contrast to necrosis.
Notionist: One whose opinions are ungrounded notions.
Nullibiety: The state or condition of being nowhere.
Nightfall: The close of the day; the arrival of the night; the period at and just after dusk.
nay: No; -- a negative answer to a question asked, or a request made, now superseded by no.  Opposed to aye or yea. See also Yes.
Nauseous: Causing, or fitted to cause, nausea; sickening; loathsome; disgusting; exciting abhorrence; as, a nauseous drug or medicine.
Numismatics: The science of coins and medals.
neocortex: The cortical part of the neencephalon; the most recently evolved part of the cerebral cortex of the brain of higher animals, and the site of most of the higher brain functions; called also neopallium.
Nigraniline: The complex, nitrogenous, organic base and dyestuff called also aniline black.
&Verbar;Neuvaines: Prayers offered up for nine successive days.
Nautilus: The only existing genus of tetrabranchiate cephalopods.  About four species are found living in the tropical Pacific, but many other species are found fossil.  The shell is spiral, symmetrical, and chambered, or divided into several cavities by simple curved partitions, which are traversed and connected together by a continuous and nearly central tube or siphuncle. See Tetrabranchiata.
Nidulate: To make a nest, as a bird.
&Verbar;Napus: A kind of turnip. See Navew.
Necessitate: To make necessary or indispensable; to render unavoidable.
Niccolite: A mineral of a copper-red color and metallic luster; an arsenide of nickel; -- called also coppernickel, kupfernickel.
numdah: an embroidered rug made from a coarse Indian felt.
Newfanglist: One who is eager for novelties or desirous of change.
Novaculite: A variety of siliceous slate, of which hones are made; razor stone; Turkey stone; hone stone; whet slate.
Neogrammarian: One of a group of philologists who apply phonetic laws more widely and strictly than was formerly done, and who maintain that these laws admit of no real exceptions.
natural gas: The combustible gas found associated with petroleum deposits, and also in other geological formations, comprised predominantly of methane plus variable other constitutents.  It is an important source of energy, and is transported long distances by pipelines, or in a liquefied state in tankers, for commercial distribution.  Some natural gas deposits contain helium, and comprise the primary source of that rare element.
Nothofagus: A genus of beeches of temperate southern hemisphere except Africa; the southern beech.
Nullifier: One who nullifies or makes void; one who maintains the right to nullify a contract by one of the parties.
Nihilist: One who advocates the doctrine of nihilism; one who believes or teaches that nothing can be known, or asserted to exist.
needlecraft: An article or articles created or assembled by needle and thread; needlework.
&Verbar;Nuphar: A genus of plants found in the fresh-water ponds or lakes of Europe, Asia, and North America; the yellow water lily.  Cf. Nymphaea.
Nod: A dropping or bending forward of the upper part or top of anything.
Nog: To fill in, as between scantling, with brickwork.
Nob: A person in a superior position in life; a nobleman.
Not: A word used to express negation, prohibition, denial, or refusal.
Now: The present time or moment; the present.
Nor: A negative connective or particle, introducing the second member or clause of a negative proposition, following neither, or not, in the first member or clause (as or in affirmative propositions follows either).  Nor is also used sometimes in the first member for neither, and sometimes the neither is omitted and implied by the use of nor.
Noticeable: Capable of being observed; worthy of notice; likely to attract observation; conspicuous.
Nephalist: One who advocates or practices nephalism.
Nacreous: Consisting of, or resembling, nacre; pearly.
Naphthylamine: One of two basic amido derivatives of naphthalene, C10H7.NH2, forming crystalline solids.
non-Jew: A person who is not Jewish.
nonmigratory: Not participating in migrations; -- used of animals that do not migrate.  Opposite of migratory.
Nonproficiency: Want of proficiency; failure to make progress.
Nonda: The edible plumlike fruit of the Australian tree, Parinarium Nonda.
Nonmember: One who is not a member; as, nonmembers are not allowed in the club reading room.
Nixie clerk: A post-office clerk in charge of the nixies.
Negus: A beverage made of wine, water, sugar, nutmeg, and lemon juice; -- so called, it is said, from its first maker, Colonel Negus.
Nippers: Small pinchers for holding, breaking, or cutting.
Nondo: A coarse umbelliferous plant (Ligusticum actæifolium) with a large aromatic root.  It is found chiefly in the Alleghany region.  Also called Angelico.
Northward: Toward the north, or toward a point nearer to the north than to the east or west point.
Neanderthal: A neanderthal human being; a member of the race Homo sapiens neanderthalensis; as, neanderthals were shorter than modern humans.
Nocturne: A night piece, or serenade. The name is now used for a certain graceful and expressive form of instrumental composition, as the nocturne for orchestra in Mendelsohn's “Midsummer-Night's Dream” music.
Nonoxygenous: Without oxygen; characterized by the absence of oxygen; as, a nonoxygenous alkaloid.
nighthawk: A person who likes to be active late at night; a night owl.
Nickle: The European woodpecker, or yaffle; -- called also nicker pecker.
Neolithic: Of or pertaining to, or designating, an era characterized by late remains in stone; the late stone age.  Estimated as beginning around 9000 b. c. in the Middle East, this period is characterized by the beginnings of farming, the domestication of animals, and the manufacture of textiles and pottery.
nonrecreational: involving gainful employment in something often done as a hobby; as, nonrecreational footbal.
Necessity: The quality or state of being necessary, unavoidable, or absolutely requisite; inevitableness; indispensableness.
&Verbar;Nebalia: A genus of small marine Crustacea, considered the type of a distinct order (Nebaloidea, or Phyllocarida.)
Nautically: In a nautical manner; with reference to nautical affairs.
Nitrosalicylic: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a nitro derivative of salicylic acid, called also anilic acid.
Norfolk dumpling: A kind of boiled dumpling made in Norfolk.
Nugget: A lump; a mass, esp. a native lump of a precious metal; as, a nugget of gold.
Nigrosine: A dark blue dyestuff, of the induline group; -- called also azodiphenyl blue.
ninepenny: 2-3/4 in or 7 cm long; -- used of nail size; as, a ninepenny nail.
Niellist: One who practices the style of ornamentation called niello.
Necropolis: A city of the dead; a name given by the ancients to their cemeteries, and sometimes applied to modern burial places; a graveyard.
Nicotine: An alkaloid which is the active principle of tobacco (C10H14N2).  It occurs in tobacco plants (Nicotiana tabacum and Nicotiana rusticum) to the extent of 2 to 8%, in combination with malic acid or citric acid.  It is a colorless, transparent, oily liquid, having an acrid odor, and an acrid burning taste.  It is intensely poisonous.  The apparently addictive effects of tobacco smoking have been ascribed largely to the effect of nicotine, and the controlled administration of nicotine on various forms has been used as a technique for assisting efforts to stop the smoking habit.
Noway: In no manner or degree; not at all; nowise.
Nephoscope: An instrument for observing the clouds and their velocity.
&Verbar;Neocarida: The modern, or true, Crustacea, as distinguished from the Merostomata.
Nipping: Biting; pinching; painful; destructive; as, a nipping frost; a nipping wind.
&Verbar;Nicotiana: A genus of American and Asiatic solanaceous herbs, with viscid foliage and funnel-shaped blossoms.  Several species yield tobacco. See Tobacco.
Northing: Distance northward from any point of departure or of reckoning, measured on a meridian; -- opposed to southing.
Naphthalic: Pertaining to, derived from, or related to, naphthalene; -- formerly used to denote any one of a series of acids derived from naphthalene, and called naphthalene acids, now specifically referring to 1,8-naphthalenedicaboxylic acid, C12H8O4.
Negation: The act of denying; assertion of the nonreality or untruthfulness of anything; declaration that something is not, or has not been, or will not be; denial; -- the opposite of affirmation.
name-dropping: The practice of casually mentioning important people in order to impress one's listener.
Nice: Foolish; silly; simple; ignorant; also, weak; effeminate.
Nourisher: One who, or that which, nourishes.
Neutral: A person or a nation that takes no part in a contest between others; one who is neutral.
Neptunicentric: As seen from Neptune, or having Neptune as a center; as, Neptunicentric longitude or force.
Necessarianism: The doctrine of philosophical necessity; necessitarianism.
Novel: That which is new or unusual; a novelty.
Neuropathy: An affection of the nervous system or of a nerve.
Nonregardance: Want of due regard; disregard; slight.
Naiad: A water nymph; one of the lower female divinities, fabled to preside over some body of fresh water, as a lake, river, brook, or fountain.
Namaycush: A large North American lake trout (Salvelinus namaycush).  It is usually spotted with red, and sometimes weighs over forty pounds.  Called also Mackinaw trout, lake trout, lake salmon, salmon trout, togue, and tuladi.
newsless: not having or receiving news or information.
nonthematic: having no theme.  Opposite of thematic.
Nitrobacteriaceae: A natural family of usually rod-shaped bacteria that oxidize ammonia or nitrites: nitrobacteria.
Nineholes: A game in which nine holes are made in the ground, into which a ball is bowled.
Nepotism: Undue attachment to relations; favoritism shown to members of one's family; bestowal of patronage in consideration of relationship, rather than of merit or of legal claim.
Nephew: A grandson or grandchild, or remoter lineal descendant.
Nationalism: The state of being national; national attachment; nationality.
Neutralizer: One who, or that which, neutralizes; that which destroys, disguises, or renders inert the peculiar properties of a body.
Northern: Of or pertaining to the north; being in the north, or nearer to that point than to the east or west.
Nervimotor: Any agent capable of causing nervimotion.
nonimitative: not marked by or given to imitation.  Opposite of imitative.
Notation: The act or practice of recording anything by marks, figures, or characters.
nonarboreal: not arboreal; not living in trees; -- of animals.  Opposite of arboreal.
Neatress: A woman who takes care of cattle.
nark: A law enforcement agent specializing in narcotics law violations.
Normalization: Reduction to a standard or normal state.
Nominatively: In the manner of a nominative; as a nominative.
Nonnecessity: Absence of necessity; the quality or state of being unnecessary.
Nugacity: Futility; trifling talk or behavior; drollery.
Needlework: Work executed with a needle; sewed work; sewing; embroidery, crocheting, quilting, or tapestry, etc.; also, the art, process, or occupation of creating objects with needles.
Necrology: An account of deaths, or of the dead; a register of deaths; a collection of obituary notices.
noncurrent: not current or belonging to the present time.  Opposite of current.
non-finite: Infinitive, uninflected; -- of verbs.   Opposite of finite.
Non-pros: To decline or fail to prosecute; to allow to be dropped (said of a suit); to enter judgment against (a plaintiff who fails to prosecute); as, the plaintiff was non-prossed.
nontechnical: not characteristic of or skilled in applied arts and sciences; as, nontechnical aspects of the job; nontechnical training.  Opposite of technical.
nonstarter: a person with a record of failing.
necklace: A string of beads, etc., or any continuous band or chain, worn around the neck as an ornament.
Nasalis: A genus of mammals comprising the proboscis monkeys.
Nominalism: The principles or philosophy of the Nominalists.
Ninepins: A game played with nine pins, or pieces of wood, set on end, at which a wooden ball is bowled to knock them down; bowling.
Neoterism: An innovation or novelty; a neoteric word or phrase.
Novatian: One of the sect of Novatius, or Novatianus, who held that the lapsed might not be received again into communion with the church, and that second marriages are unlawful.
Nataloin: A bitter crystalline substance constituting the essential principle of Natal aloes.  Cf. Aloon.
Nidor: Scent or savor of meat or food, cooked or cooking.
Nigritude: Blackness; the state of being black.
Nominalist: One of a sect of philosophers in the Middle Ages, who adopted the opinion of Roscelin, that general conceptions, or universals, exist in name only.
Neoterist: One who introduces new words or phrases; a neologist.
Nasiform: Having the shape of a nose.
nonwoody: not woody; not consisting of or resembling wood; as, nonwoody plants.  Opposite of woody.
Nodular: Of or pertaining to a nodule or knot.
nostalgia: Homesickness; esp., a severe and sometimes fatal form of melancholia, due to homesickness.
Negro: Of or pertaining to negroes; black.
Noted: Well known by reputation or report; eminent; famous; prominent; celebrated; as, a noted author, or traveler.
Notionally: In mental apprehension; in conception; not in reality.
Necrosed: Affected by necrosis; dead; as, a necrosed bone.
Niceness: Quality or state of being nice.
Niding: A coward; a dastard; -- a term of utmost opprobrium.
Nightgown: A loose gown used for undress; also, a gown used for a sleeping garment.
Negligible: That may be neglected, disregarded, or left out of consideration; too small or unimportant to be worthy of notice.
nibs: See his nibs under nib, n.
Nurl: To cut with reeding or fluting on the edge of, as coins, the heads of screws, etc.; to knurl.
Nervimotion: The movement caused in the sensory organs by external agents and transmitted to the muscles by the nerves.
Noteworthy: Worthy of observation or notice; remarkable.
Nobly: Of noble extraction; as, nobly born or descended.
Nickelous: Of, pertaining to, or designating, those compounds of nickel in which, as contrasted with the nickelic compounds, the metal has a lower valence; as, nickelous oxide.
Neoplasty: Restoration of a part by granulation, adhesive inflammation, or autoplasty.
&Verbar;Neurosis: A functional nervous affection or disease, that is, a disease of the nerves without any appreciable change of nerve structure.
Novelist: An innovator; an asserter of novelty.
Nitroform: A nitro derivative of methane, analogous to chloroform, obtained as a colorless oily or crystalline substance, CH.(NO2)3, quite explosive, and having well-defined acid properties.
Network: A fabric of threads, cords, or wires crossing each other at certain intervals, and knotted or secured at the crossings, thus leaving spaces or meshes between them.
&Verbar;Nummulites: A genus of extinct Tertiary Foraminifera, having a thin, flat, round shell, containing a large number of small chambers arranged spirally.
necromania: An abnormal attraction to dead bodies.
Next: In the time, place, or order nearest or immediately succeeding; as, this man follows next.
Niggerhead: A strong black chewing tobacco, usually in twisted plug form; negro head.
Nombril: A point halfway between the fess point and the middle base point of an escutcheon; -- called also navel point. See Escutcheon.
Nabob: A deputy or viceroy in India; a governor of a province of the ancient Mogul empire.
Nodation: Act of making a knot, or state of being knotted.
Nitric: Of, pertaining to, or containing, nitrogen; specifically, designating any one of those compounds in which, as contrasted with nitrous compounds, the element has a higher valence; as, nitric oxide; nitric acid.
Noose: To tie in a noose; to catch in a noose; to entrap; to insnare.
navel orange: A type of orange in which the fruit incloses a small secondary fruit, the rind showing on the exterior a navel-like pit or depression at the apex.  There are several varieties; they are usually seedless, or nearly so, and are much grown in California.
Noise: To spread by rumor or report.
nondenominational: not restricted to a particular religious denomination; as, a nondenominational school.
Noetian: One of the followers of Noetus, who lived in the third century.  He denied the distinct personality of the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost.
Nuclear physicist: A scientist specializing in nuclear physics.
Neutrally: In a neutral manner; without taking part with either side; indifferently.
nicotinic acid: An organic acid (C6H5NO2), a carboxylated derivative of pyridine, obtained by the oxidation of nicotine; called also niacin and antipellagra vitamin, and vitamin B5.  Chemically it is 3-pyridinecarboxylic acid.
&Verbar;Nehiloth: A term supposed to mean, perforated wind instruments of music, as pipes or flutes.
Nepotal: Of or relating to a nephew.
Nearly: In a near manner; not remotely; closely; intimately; almost; as, he nearly lost his life in the accident.
Nymphalidae: A natural family of large beautifully colored butterflies, called also the brush-footed butterflies; formerly called Nymphales.
Noisy: Making a noise, esp. a loud sound; clamorous; vociferous; turbulent; boisterous; as, the noisy crowd.
nonmechanical: not using a mechanism.  Opposite of mechanical.
Nativism: The disposition to favor the native inhabitants of a country, in preference to immigrants from foreign countries.
Nodose: Knotty; having numerous or conspicuous nodes.
Neptune: The son of Saturn and Ops, the god of the waters, especially of the sea.  He is represented as bearing a trident for a scepter.
Narrative: That which is narrated; the recital of a story; a continuous account of the particulars of an event or transaction; a story.
Nominalistic: Of or pertaining to the Nominalists.
Nonnitrogenous: Devoid of nitrogen; as, a nonnitrogenous principle; a nonnitrogenous food.  See the Note under Food, n., 1.
&Verbar;N\u00e6vus: A spot or mark on the skin of children when born; a birthmark; -- the term includes moles as wells a other types of birthmark, and is most commonly applied to reddish or brownish raised vascular areas of the skin, i. e., those consisting mainly of blood vessels, as dilated arteries, veins, or capillaries.
Neurility: The special properties and functions of the nerves; that capacity for transmitting a stimulus which belongs to nerves.
normalcy: The quality, state, or fact of being normal; the normal situation or condition; as, the point of normalcy.
Navigate: To pass over in ships; to sail over or on; as, to navigate the Atlantic.
Nunnish: Of, pertaining to, or resembling a nun; characteristic of a nun.
Nickar nut: Same as Nicker nut, Nicker tree.
Nucleolar: Of or pertaining to the nucleolus of a cell.
nonsectarian: not restricted to one sect or school or party; as, religious training in a nonsectarian atmosphere; public funding is restricted to nonsectarian colleges.  Opposite of sectarian.
Ninigi: The grandson of Amaterasu and first ruler of Japan.
Nitrogelatin: An explosive consisting of gun cotton and camphor dissolved in nitroglycerin.
Norma: A norm; a principle or rule; a model; a standard.
Nicotidine: A complex, oily, nitrogenous base, isomeric with nicotine, and obtained by the reduction of certain derivatives of the pyridine group.
Neer-do-well: A person who never does, or fares, well; a good for nothing.
Necessitarianism: The doctrine of philosophical necessity; the doctrine that results follow by invariable sequence from causes, and esp. that the will is not free, but that human actions and choices result inevitably from motives; determinism.
-ness: A suffix used to form abstract nouns expressive of quality or state; as, goodness, greatness.
Nipa: A monotypic genus of palms of Australasia.
Noncompletion: Lack of completion; failure to complete.
Namation: A distraining or levying of a distress; an impounding.
Nard: An East Indian plant (Nardostachys Jatamansi) of the Valerian family, used from remote ages in Oriental perfumery.
Naturally: In a natural manner or way; according to the usual course of things; spontaneously.
Northness: A tendency in the end of a magnetic needle to point to the north.
neutrosophy:
A branch of philosophy, introduced by Florentin Smarandache in 1980, which studies
 the origin, nature, and scope of neutralities, as well as their interactions with different ideational spectra.  

Neutrosophy considers a proposition, theory, event, concept, or entity, “A” in relation to its opposite, “Anti-A” and that which is not A, “Non-A”, and that which is
 neither “A” nor “Anti-A”, denoted by “Neut-A”.  Neutrosophy is the basis of neutrosophic logic, neutrosophic probability, neutrosophic set, and neutrosophic 
statistics.
Nickname: To give a nickname to; to call by a nickname.
&Verbar;Neuropteris: An extensive genus of fossil ferns, of which species have been found from the Devonian to the Triassic formation.
Nibelungenlied: A great medieval German epic of unknown authorship containing traditions which refer to the Burgundians at the time of Attila (called Etzel in the poem) and mythological elements pointing to heathen times.
nonvocalic: not vocalic; not having vowel character; -- used of liquids and nasals.  Opposite of vocalic.
Neuter: A person who takes no part in a contest; one who is either indifferent to a cause or forbears to interfere; a neutral.
Neurine: A poisonous organic base (a ptomaine) formed in the decomposition of protagon with boiling baryta water, and in the putrefaction of proteid matter.  It was for a long time considered identical with choline, a crystalline body originally obtained from bile.  Chemically, however, choline is oxyethyl-trimethyl-ammonium hydroxide, while neurine is vinyl-trimethyl-ammonium hydroxide.
&Verbar;Neoplasia: Growth or development of new material; neoplasty.
Noviceship: The state of being a novice; novitiate.
non-U: Not characteristic of the upper classes especially in language use.
Notochord: An elastic cartilagelike rod which is developed beneath the medullary groove in the vertebrate embryo, and constitutes the primitive axial skeleton around which the centra of the vertebræ and the posterior part of the base of the skull are developed; the chorda dorsalis. See Illust. of Ectoderm.
Nitter: The horse louse; an insect that deposits nits on horses.
Najas: The sole genus of the family Naiadaceae.
Nectary: That part of a blossom which secretes nectar, usually the base of the corolla or petals; also, the spur of such flowers as the larkspur and columbine, whether nectariferous or not. See the Illustration of Nasturtium.
Negotiable: Capable of being negotiated; transferable by assignment or indorsement to another person; as, a negotiable note or bill of exchange.
Newsy: Full of news; abounding in information as to current events.
Nonagon: A plane figure or polygon having nine sides and nine angles.
&Verbar;Non est factum: The plea of the general issue in an action of debt on bond.
Night terrors: A sudden awakening associated with a sensation of terror, occurring in children, esp. those of unstable nervous constitution.
&Verbar;Nova: A star which suddenly increases in brightness thousands of times, then fades back to near its original intensity.  It may appear as a “new” star if its original brightness was too low for routine observation.  A star which suddenly increases in brightness to many millions of times its original intensity is a supernova, and the postulated mechanisms for the increases of brightness of novae and supernovae are different.
&Verbar;Nonconstat: It does not appear; it is not plain or clear; it does not follow.
Nonylenic: Of, pertaining to, related to, or designating, nonylene or its compounds; as, nonylenic acid.
niacinamide: The amide of niacin (nicotinic acid), called also nicotinamide.  It was at one time called vitamin B3, and can function to relieve nicotinic acid deficiency.  Chemical formula C6H6N2O, chemically it is 3-pyridinecarboxamide.
Nonobservance: Neglect or failure to observe or fulfill.
Neutralist: A neutral; one who professes or practices neutrality.
Newsmonger: One who deals in news; one who is active in hearing and telling news.
nucleotide: a phosphate ester of a nucleoside; one of the monomeric components of DNA or RNA.
Nymphalis: The type genus of the Nymphalidae, including the mourning cloak butterfly (Nymphalis antiopa).
nonprescription: able to be sold legally without a doctor's prescription; over-the-counter; -- of medicinal drugs; as, Aspirin is a nonprescription antiinflammatory drug.  Opposite of prescription.
Nonconduction: The quality of not being able to conduct or transmit; failure to conduct.
Nyctophile: Any Australian bat of the genus Nyctophilus, having a very simple nasal appendage.
Nagyagite: A mineral of blackish lead-gray color and metallic luster, generally of a foliated massive structure; foliated tellurium.  It is a telluride of lead and gold.
Natant: Floating in water, as the leaves of water lilies, or submersed, as those of many aquatic plants.
neatness: The state or quality of being neat.
Namely: By name; by particular mention; specifically; especially; expressly.
Nusku: The god of fire and light; corresponds to the Babylonian Girru.
Neoplatonist: One who held to Neoplatonism; a member of the Neoplatonic school.
Nearsighted: Seeing distinctly at short distances only; myopic; shortsighted.
Nandine: An African carnivore (Nandinia binotata), allied to the civets. It is spotted with black.
Nestorianism: The doctrines of the Nestorian Christians, or of Nestorius.
Nicety: The quality or state of being nice (in any of the senses of that word.).
nonhierarchic: Not arranged in a hierarchy.  Opposite of hierarchical.
Nail-headed: Having a head like that of a nail; formed so as to resemble the head of a nail.
Neoplatonism: A pantheistic eclectic school of philosophy, of which Plotinus was the chief (a. d. 205-270), and which sought to reconcile the Platonic and Aristotelian systems with Oriental theosophy.  It tended to mysticism and theurgy, and was the last product of Greek philosophy.
nearer: less distant in space; as, we walked to the nearer house.
Nylghau: A large Asiatic antelope (Boselaphus tragocamelus, syn. Portax tragocamelus), found in Northern India; called also the blue bull.  It has short horns, a black mane, and a bunch of long hair on the throat.  The general color is grayish brown; the male is blue-grey with white markings, and the female is brownish with no horns.
Noils: Waste and knots of wool removed by the comb; combings.
nightrobe: A loose dress designed to be worn in bed by women; a nightgown.
ninepin: a bowling pin of the type used in ninepins (or (in England) skittles).
Nightman: One whose business is emptying privies by night.
News-writer: One who gathers news for, and writes, news-letters, articles in news periodicals, or items for broadcast on news programs.
Nearness: The state or quality of being near; -- used in the various senses of the adjective.
nonliterate: not using a writing system; -- of societies, cultures, or tribes.
Notoriety: The quality or condition of being notorious; the state of being generally or publicly known; -- commonly used in an unfavorable sense; as, the notoriety of a crime.
Nobby: Stylish; modish; elegant; showy; aristocratic; fashionable.
Nyctitropism: The tendency of certain plant organs, as leaves, to assume special “sleeping” positions or make curvatures under the influence of darkness. It is well illustrated in the leaflets of clover and other leguminous plants.
Nanism: The condition of being abnormally small in stature; dwarfism; dwarfishness; -- opposed to gigantism.
Nightingale: A small, plain, brown and gray European song bird (Luscinia megarhynchos syn. Luscinia luscinia). It sings at night, and is celebrated for the sweetness of its song.
nongregarious: Not growing or living in groups or colonies; -- of plants and animals.
Narrow: To become less broad; to contract; to become narrower; as, the sea narrows into a strait.
nonrigid: Not rigid; especially, designating an airship having a shape maintained only by internal gas pressure and without a supporting structure.  Opposite of rigid.
Nectariferous: Secreting nectar; -- said of blossoms or their parts.
Neologistic: Of or pertaining to neology; neological.
Nonjuring: Not swearing allegiance; -- applied to the party in Great Britain that would not swear allegiance to William and Mary, or their successors.
Nonconforming: Not conforming; declining conformity; especially, not conforming to the established church of a country.
Nontronite: A greenish yellow or green mineral, consisting chiefly of the hydrous silicate of iron.
Notional: Consisting of, or conveying, notions or ideas; expressing abstract conceptions.
&Verbar;Nucleoidioplasma: Hyaline plasma contained in the nucleus of vegetable cells.
national: A citizen (of a particular country); as, U. S. nationals are advised to contact their embassy when abroad.
Neoplasm: A new formation or tissue, the product of morbid action.
Niche: A cavity, hollow, or recess, generally within the thickness of a wall, for a statue, bust, or other erect ornament.  Hence, any similar position, literal or figurative.
Nightjar: A goatsucker, esp. the European species. See Illust. of Goatsucker.
Nimbus: A circle, or disk, or any indication of radiant light around the heads of divinities, saints, and sovereigns, upon medals, pictures, etc.; a halo. See Aureola, and Glory, n., 5.
nondecisive: not crucial; not comprising a decisive factor in a result.  Opposite of crucial and decisive.
Nomadism: The state of being a nomad.
Nanny: a caretaker for a child; a child's nurse; a nursemaid.
Nolition: Adverse action of will; unwillingness; -- opposed to volition.
Narragansetts: A tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited the shores of Narragansett Bay.
Nitrify: To combine or impregnate with nitrogen; to convert, by oxidation, into nitrous or nitric acid; to subject to, or produce by, nitrification.
Nonelectric: A substance that is not an insulator (i. e., an electric); that which transmits electricity, as a metal; a conductor.
neonatal: of or pertaining to a neonate; as, neonatal care; a neonatal unit at a hospital.
Nonterm: A vacation between two terms of a court.
Net-veined: Having veins, or nerves, reticulated or netted; as, a net-veined wing or leaf.
Nonagrian: Any moth of the genus Nonagria and allied genera, as the spindleworm and stalk borer.
Nocake: Indian corn parched, and beaten to powder, -- used for food by the Northern American Indians.
Norseman: One of the ancient Scandinavians; a Northman.
normotensive: Pertaining to or having normal blood pressure.
Naiadaceae: A monotypic family of aquatic plants having narrow leaves and small flowers.
&Verbar;Non assumpsit: The general plea or denial in an action of assumpsit.
Neo-Darwinism: The theory which holds natural selection, as explained by Darwin, to be the chief factor in the evolution of plants and animals, and denies the inheritance of acquired characters; -- esp. opposed to Neo-Lamarckism. Weismannism is an example of extreme Neo-Darwinism.
Netball: A team game that resembles basketball; a soccer ball is to be thrown so that it passes through a ring on the top of a post.
Nitrosaccharin: An explosive nitro derivative of certain sugars, analogous to nitroglycerin, gun cotton, etc.
Nitrosylic: Of, pertaining to, or containing, nitrosyl; as, nitrosylic acid.
Niblick: A kind of golf stick used to lift the ball out of holes, ruts, etc.
narrowed: reduced in size as if by being squeezed.
Nontenure: A plea of a defendant that he did not hold the land, as affirmed.
neuropsychology: the branch of psychology that is concerned with the physiological bases of psychological processes.
